elements.text: [Part One]
Doctor - doors - open up! Quick!
Door opens.
Ace. Is Hex not with you?
He's just here. Oh. Oh, what's happened to him now?
(distant) Hey! Hey! Wait for me! I'm coming! I'm coming!
Oh dear.
Oh, I'll get him.
Roar.
Be careful, Ace. That thing's going to...
Giant sneeze.
Blow.
Oh, man! Oh no.
Splash.
Argh.
Hex.
It's all over me. I can't move.
Take my hand. Urgh. Other hand.
(distant) Hurry up. Looks like it's building up for another one.
Squelch.
That's it. Got you.
Ah! I'm covered in s...
Never mind that. Run! How long have we got?
About er ten seconds. Nine, eight...
That's another fine mess you've got me into.
Five, four...
Shut up and drive!
Three, two... oh.
+ HEX: Doors.
Good trip, you two?
You're joking, aren't ya? Look at the state of me.
I don't know. Maybe your trousers look better shiny.
They're not shiny. They're muc'd.
Get away from me. You need a shower.
I need a really big hanky. I think I've got to go and blow my pants.
Towels in emergency bathroom. Second left.
Third left.
Third left! Honestly, I don't know. What's wrong with a bit of nasal slime?
You knew that was out there, didn't you? You had a funny look on your face the moment you found out that place was called... what was it? Akinajoof?
Yes. It can mean either Forest of Delicious Fruits, or Snot Monster's Garden. It really depends which translation you use.
Mmm.
Now. (hums)
Doctor?
Yes?
How come we never do anything pleasant? You know, nice.
Nice?
Yeah, you know, nice. I just want a break.
A break?
A break. A day off. A week, even.
Where?
Er...
Come on, the universe is a big place. You have to be specific.
Well, we could, er... Oh. Er...
Time's ticking away. Always ticking. Tick. What's the other one? Oh, tock, yes that's it. Tick tock.
You're putting me on the spot. Have you got any brochures?
This is a Time and Space machine, not a travel agent's. Of course I don't have any...
Hey, what are all these brochures doing in the bog?
Brochures.
Ah. I was wondering what had happened to those. They must have been misplaced when the Tardis architecture last reconfigured itself.
Must have.
Hey! The Death Well of Mindar. Is that a ride?
No. It's a death well. Try one without a screaming face on the front. They're more humanoid friendly.
The Eye Boiling Vat of Pain at Fringan. Hex?
Ah, I dunno. Something about the name's putting me off. Here you are, here's one. The Festival of the Twin Moons of Tuin.
Ah, The Festival of the Twin Moons of Tuin. That takes me back.
Well , what is it?
Well, it's a festival, of the planet Tuin, and it involves the twin moons.
I think we got that, Doctor.
Er, yeah. Can you be a bit more specific?
The Festival of the Twin Moons of Tuin takes place once every five hundred Tuin years, which is approximately...
Five hundred Earth years?
Approximately. It's a celebration of all the good aspects of the planet Tuin, and it takes the form of a week-long party with music and dancing.
Well, that sounds all right. Music and dancing. Like Glastonbury. Will there be a beer tent?
Oh, almost certainly. The planet Tuin has often been referred to as the Brewery of the Galaxy.
Ah, so there might be the odd lager knocking about.
Read that.
The beer houses of Tuin boast as many as fourteen hundred varieties of ale. Great, what are we waiting for? Let's go.
Hang on! I want a break, not a booze-up.
Next paragraph?
Er, the Festival of Tuin is also noted for its emphasis on peace and relaxation. Spas fully-equipped with... Wow! All right then, I'm sold.
Very well. I suppose the Tardis could use an airing.
Hurrah! Planet Ale, here we come!
The Tardis dematerialises.
Mind you, if you want beer, The Eye Boiling Vat of Pain at Fringan does a very nice pint.
Yeah, but with a name like that, it's got to be part of a chain.
The Tardis materialises, door opens and closes.
Bit bleak. You're sure this is Tuin?
Yes. It does seem somewhat overcast.
Yeah, but there's not a cloud in the sky.
Well observed, Master Hex. So, we must be overcast by... Ah!
That massive great big enormous huge giant pillar behind us?
The one that's as tall as the Empire State Building and twice as wide? You reckon?
Caught your eye too, did it?
(distant) Come on!
What does he mean, come on? Hurry up, it's lunch time, or...
Or, follow me, I've had an idea and I'm too brainy to explain it to you, then later something awful will happen and he'll apologise for not mentioning it earlier.
Hmm. Sounds like fun.
What, unpleasantness, fear, boredom, danger and weird alien creatures sounds like fun?
Yeah. It's not that different to [?7], really.
(distant) I've found something!
Here we go. He's found something. Where are you?
(distant) Over the ridge.
What ridge? Ah!
That ridge. Hey. Are those graves?
Nah. There's miles and miles of them. The whole planet'd have to be a graveyard.
You know, I think this whole planet is a graveyard.
Great.
RI COMPUTER 1: (male) Alert. Sensors detect super space chatter on [??] surface.
RI COMPUTER 2: (female) Recount chatter.
RI COMPUTER 1: Recounting.
[OC]: You know, I think this whole planet is a graveyard.
RI COMPUTER 2: These are not Ri.
RI COMPUTER 1: Then they must be Ir.
RI COMPUTER 2: Follicle count says these are not Ir.
RI COMPUTER 1: Then they must be Ir spies.
RI COMPUTER 1 + RI COMPUTER 2: And Ir must be destroyed.
RI COMPUTER 2: Despatch nearest Ri sentinel.

RI COMPUTER 1: Nearest Ri Sentinel. Senior Infantry Fighter Ori, from the Second Corps of Those Prepared For Death, Third Battalion, Carrion Of Tomorrow regiment. Brigade of Bones Scattered Across the Boundary of...
RI COMPUTER 2: Sentinel is adequately locked. Despatching Senior Infantry Fighter Ori. Find the Ir spies. Destroy the Ir. Destroy.
What's so interesting, Doctor?
The markings on this pillar. Fascinating.
It's a mural. They had one outside our community centre, only it got graffiti'd. Nobody found out who did it, but I got the blame.
Fascinating.
Maybe if I hadn't have signed it.
Hex?
Oh, sorry. Yeah, go on.
Thank you. This particular mural is ancient. Legends and lore going back thousands of years, and...
Well, it's a war memorial, isn't it? Look, these blokes here, fighting these blokes here...
I'm not so sure.
Doctor, you said this was a place of peace and tranquillity.
And beer.
Well, it's peaceful enough now. I'm sorry. Sometimes the Tardis misses its target.
Sometimes? Doctor, sundials at night are more accurate than the Tardis. Underwater sundials at night are more accurate than the Tardis.
A tragedy of this scale must have quite a story behind it.
Just for once I wanted a world without a story, Doctor. Not the past, not the future, just the present.
Oh, very well. I'll just gather some data here, and then we'll pop back a few thousand years and have a holiday.
What, here? Knowing what's going to happen to all these people?
Ace, every world I visit, every civilisation I come across, I go there knowing that one day it'll end. In war or catastrophe or just in the sudden snuffing out of a sun.
And I thought me Mam could put a downer on a holiday. Look, I'm with Ace. I don't fancy having a break around here.
Come on Hex, let's go back.
Right.

I don't tell them their civilisations are going to end. That'd be rude. I... Oh well. I suppose we could go somewhere nice. Nice. Honestly, humans. Only a planet that's had seven world wars could come up with a concept like nice. The H Bomb and the toasted teacake. Twin poles of Man's achievement. Oh. Ah, now. This is interesting. Placed here to commemorate the glorious dead. Always the same, these things. And the war that shall never end. Oh dear. It would seem that this war is still going on. Bone fields, hops and meadows. Oh dear, oh dear, oh dear, oh dear. Hmm. That's interesting. Ace, I'm busy. I'll join you and Hex in the Tardis in a... Don't poke me with that...
Energy whine..
Gun. Ah. Oh. Hello, I'm the Doctor.
Spy. Agent of Ir.
Ah, no, you see, I...
Whine, thud.
What?
+ ACE: Was that?
Trouble. Doctor?
Where are you? Doctor?
More Ir.
Oh no!
Wow! He's a bit hairy, isn't he?
Get down!
Blast. Ace gasps.
Are you okay?
Yeah, yeah.
Blast.
Oi! These are gravestones!
(spits) Ir graves.
Blast.
Don't think he cares. No sign of the Doctor.
Not unless he's been zapped already.
What is that thing?
I'm a nurse, Jim. Not a man who knows what... that thing is. But it's very ginger, and very hairy. So come on, what's our plan?
We haven't got a plan.
Why haven't we got a plan?
Shall we go back and have a meeting? I think there's a conference room somewhere in the Tardis. Maybe we could brainstorm a few ideas. You know, see what we come up with?
I'm coming to get you.
Laughs, blast.
Fair point. You know, you're very attractive when you're sarcastic.
Look, you distract whatever itis, and I'll run in and try to get the Doctor.
Distract it? With what, me holiday snaps?
Just do something. Good luck.
Brilliant. We're ten feet away from Alan the space orang-utan and his great big enormous zappy super- gun, and she wants me to run around waving me arms shouting, chase me, chase me.
I can smell you, Ir scum.
Oi! You! Simply Red! Over â€˜ere!
Blast.
Missed. Hey, guess what? I snogged your Mum. And she was rubbish!
Blast.
Doctor? Doctor.
Ace.
Eh? Where are...?
Here.
Oh. Where? Oh. You've been digging your own grave again?
Help me out.
Oh yeah. I see the problem. They bury their dead ten feet under. Hang on. Oh! If I just... lower myself...
Careful.
Just get hold of my foot. Ow!
Sorry.
Wrench it out of the socket, why don't you? Oh. Oh!
The side's giving way.
Ow!
Thud.
Ace ?
Oh... I'm fine. I think.
It's all up to Hex now. Where is he?
Distracting the alien with taunts and sexual innuendo.
And that's the full extent of your plan?
Sorry, we couldn't schedule the full brainstorm. Found you though, didn't I?
True. Ah. Unfortunately, so did our friend. And he's holding his gun to Hex's head.
Sorry.
Ir scum. I have you now.
RI COMPUTER 2: Plasmoid blast detected on Tuin surface.
RI COMPUTER 1: Recount.
RI COMPUTER 2: Recounting.
[OC]: Oi! You! Simply Red! Over 'ere!
RI COMPUTER 1: Plasmoid blasts suggests presence of Ri infantry.
RI COMPUTER 2: Low follicle count suggests their enemy is neither Ir nor Ri. Who is their enemy? RI COMPUTER 1: Despatch scout ship to investigate. Glory to Ir.
RI COMPUTER 2: Glory. Glory.
Get in.
Hey!
Hex, are you...?
Fine. I'd have just climbed in if you would have asked me nicely. Sorry about that, folks.
Suppose you did your best.
I think he got upset when I made a reference to his Auntie Marge, and a tub of margari...
Be quiet. You are all three prisoners of the army of Ri. We are the true way. We are the only force. We are Ri.
You're ginger, mate. That's what you are. Ginger all over!
Hex. It's very unwise to mock the physical appearance of another species.
Especially with mucus in your hair.
Silence. Who are you?
Well, how can we answer that, when you've just told us to be silent?
You are spies from Ir.
Oh, please. It's always spies with you people, isn't it? No one's ever a tourist, or lost, or visiting their nephew. No, it's spies every time.
We're travellers.
Just passing through. On a visit, like. Any idea where the beer tent is?

Ha! There have been no visitors here for thousands of years. Tuin is a wasteland, a desert. No life remains on Tuin. Unending war between our moon of Ri, and the enemy moon of Ir, has cursed her sorry surface. There is nothing here but the silent dead.
I told you we shouldn't have come off-season.
Look, whatever your name is, we're...
Senior Infantry Fighter Ori, from the Second Corps of Those Prepared For Death, Third Battalion, Carrion of Tomorrow Regiment, Brigade of Bones Scattered Across The Universe...
Yes, yes, yes, yes, Ori, yes. We're not here to harm you, and goodness knows, we're not interested in your war. How long did you say it's been going on for?
Ten thousand years.
Couldn't you have come up with a better way of spending ten thousand years?
The hatred between our peoples is fierce and strong.
Well, it'd be pretty stupid to be at war all this time because you found each other mildly annoying.
Look what you've done to this planet. A perfectly pleasant planet, in bits.
War brings with it its own necessities . If our homeworld should perish in our conflict, so be it.
Your homeworld? I notice you've conveniently failed to blow up your own moon in all of this.
The moon of Ri has suffered in war. See how its surface is pitted.
Your moon's still there though, isn't it? And your opponents, the Ir, they've still got their moon, so everybody's happy.
You are fools. You know nothing of the dispute between our two peoples.
I'm sure it was all terribly important at the time, but really, isn't it about time you sorted it out?
Doctor, I'm not sure this is the time to play peacemaker.

Come on, Ace. These people have been at war for ten thousand years. And over what? Somebody probably misheard somebody say something at a banquet, or dropped a comb in somebody's soup. Any one of a million stupid petty reasons which apparently justified the slaughter of millions of innocent people.
The people of Ri fired a plague missile at our capital city.
I gotta say, that is a bit steep.
We did drop a thousand lava bombs on their capital city first, but we had just cause.
Rumbling overhead.
Doctor.
What is it?
That!
[OC]: Er... Hello... Testing. (tapping twice) Er... surrender your weapons. Surrender your weapons.
Never! Die, Ir scum!
Ori, put that stupid gun down. That's a fully armed battle craft.
I shall die for Ri.
I don't think that's wise.
True. Retreat, retreat, or I shall blast your spies into oblivion.
Good intervention, Doctor.
[OC]: The Ir do not retreat.
Then watch your agents writhe in the agonies of a slow protracted death.
Ori, no!
Die! Die! Die!
Blasts, all cry out.
Wibble, whoosh.
What was that?
Tractor beam?
Attractor beam. A beam that attracts us.
Oh, I get it.
All right, snarky.
So we're inside the battle craft, do you think?
Obviously.
All right, snarky.
Which makes these gentlemen the Ir.
Surrender your weapons.
We have no weapons. We come in peace.
You do? Ah well, all the same, search them.
Oi! Tell your boot boys to back off.
Let's just cooperate, shall we, Ace?
Just watch it, Baldy.
Hang on. They're all baldy.
Oh, blimey. Right Said Fred made it into space.
We of the Ir are proud to be hairless. You show signs of redegeneracy. These shabby lank and greasy locks.
Bit personal. There's nothing lank or greasy about my hair.
Well, actually...
Oh right. Snot.
Vile.
They're clear. No mini-guns, anti-personnel mines.
Scissors, razor blades, screwdrivers, not us.
Excellent. Well now, all that remains is to kill you.
Sorry?
I expect you are. But really, there's no need. It's a painless death, and as we don't believe in an afterlife, you won't be going to Hell.
Before you do kill us...
Hey, you're giving in a bit easily, aren't ya? I really would like not to be killed.
Yeah, me too. Er, me neither.
Oh, come now. When faced with the inevitable, you really ought to just sit back and accept it.
Doctor, this isn't a visit to the dentist. They're gonna to kill us.
Yes, and we'd like to do it sooner rather than later, if you don't mind.
Of course. But before you do complete your no doubt completely necessary task...
Yes?
You couldn't tell me, why is it completely necessary?
Well, because there's a war on.
Oh, I see.
And it wouldn't be much of a war if we didn't kill anyone, would it?
I suppose not. Well, thank you for sorting that out.

Not at all. It's nice to see such an understanding attitude in a foe. Most of them are so self-centred when it comes to death. Foolish really when a time like... well, like this should be an occasion for composing oneself, not screaming and running around begging for things.
Begging for things?
Things, yes. Mercy, life, that sort of carry-on. Anyway, time moves on and I'd love to talk, but you know how it is.
Doctor, can you hear...?
Yes I can. There's one more thing...
There always is, but now we really must terminate your existence. Existences. I never get that right.
Have you noticed that sound?
What sound?
The loud one?
I believe it's an all-clear, Ace. But I'd like my friend from the Ir to confirm that.
Oh, all right. That sound, as I suspect you know, is a signal.
The signal, in fact.
Yes. It's the Sign of Commencement.

The Sign of Commencement. A giant klaxon created in a brief moment of truce 9500 years ago and now sounded once every five hundred years. It indicates the start of the most important event in the calendar of the Twin Moons of Tuin.
Could that be the Festival of the Twin Moons of Tuin?
So the festival's still on? Great! Mine's a pint.

Not only does the Sign of Commencement signal the start of Tuin's most revered festival - and yes, Hex, opening time - the only occasion in fact where Ir and Ri are briefly at peace. But also... Oh, you tell them.
The end of any hostilities for the period of the festival.
They can't execute us now!
As you very well knew. Come, my fellow Ir, we must land on Tuin and prepare the Festival.
Hey, what about us?
Detract them.
You wha...?
Wibble, whoosh.
De-tractor beam. I get it.
Quite. Detracted back whence we came.
Hang on. Up there, were you playing for time?
Oh Hex, duh!

Having made certain calculations based on the alignment of the Pillar of Remembrance and the positioning of the Moons, it was a simple matter to check my hunch that we had arrived less than an hour before the Sign of Commencement would occur.
I don't get it. I thought this Festival was out the window, on account of the war and that.
Oh Hex, this Festival is the only way of ending the war, which is why we're here.
He's done it again. The whole thing was deliberate from the start. We never were going on holiday, were we? This was never a break. You never got the date wrong.
You mean you planted those brochures in the Tardis bog?
What suspicious minds you have.
Stand still.
Ah, no. The ginger minger's back.
The Ir chose not to kill you, I see. Therefore you must be their allies. So I must kill you.
Clock the klaxon? It's Festival time, mate. You can't kill us.
Well? Get out of that.
Is he gonna cry?
You have shamed me, for I had you at my mercy, and failed to deliver the killing shot.
Honestly, some aliens.
I ask only that you accept the hospitality of the Ri.
I think he's going to buy you a pint, Hex.
He is? Brilliant! Where's the beer tent, then?
Party sounds and drums.
Cheers, Ori.
Health to you, and painful bowel diseases to your enemies.
Hey, you should have this Festival more often. It's all right.
Ah, once this Festival took place yearly, Hox. People came from Ir and Ri, and the ocean cities of Deep Tuin, to the mountain folk of High Tuin.
So people lived on Tuin once too? Not just you lot and the Ir?

Tuin was the world that birthed us. Tuin was our mother, and we its children. When dispute came, Tuin was ravaged, and we and the Ir retreated to our Moons. But still we fight for our murdered mother. Still, Hox, we fight!
Er, calm down Ori. I was just asking. Hey, and stop calling me Hox. It's Hex.
ORI laughs.
Sorry, did I say something funny?
No, it's just your name.
And what's wrong with my name?
Hex. It means something else in my tongue.
Oh yeah? Like what?
I shall draw a picture of one in this pool of ale.
Oh. Oh, fair enough. Yeah, don't call me Hex.
Never mind, little Hox. Down in one. Three, two, one!
Hex seems to be well in with that Ori.
The Ri are people of their word.
What about the other lot, the Ir?
So long as the Festival is on, nobody can lay a finger on anyone else.
Are you sure?
Ace, this Festival is so old, keeping the peace is virtually encoded in their DNA.
You seem to know a lot about this place, Doctor.
Yes, well, one makes a study of these things.
More than a study. What was that you said back there about ending the war?
Hmm.
Doctor? What are you up to?
Let us drink more ale.
Good idea! No, no, it's my round. Oh, hang on. Doctor? Doctor, what do we do about dosh?
I take it the beer is recommending itself to you?
Hey, it's the business. I am rockin"!
You sure about that?
Give it a minute. It's kickinâ€™ in. I'll be well on me way in no time!
I doubt it, Hex. Since the war, all Tuinese beer has been strictly alcohol free.
What?
There's a war on, you know. Now, Ori?
Doctor.
I need your help.
Anything. I shall burn your likeness into my fur. I shall put my fingers into the mouth of a Tooth fish. I...
I'll bear that in mind, but for now, I just want to meet a priest.
A priest? You wish to honour the traditions of the Ri?
Well, partly. But mostly, I want to do what I came here to do.
Which is what?
Which is to end this war. It's gone on far too long.
End the war, Doctor? End millennia of conflict, you?
Yes, me.
And how are you going to do that?
Oh, that's easy. I'm going to get married.

ACE: He's just here. Oh. Oh, what's happened to him now?
HEX: (distant) Hey! Hey! Wait for me! I'm coming! I'm coming!
DOCTOR: Oh dear.
ACE: Oh, I'll get him.
DOCTOR: Be careful, Ace. That thing's going to...
DOCTOR: Blow.
HEX: Oh, man! Oh no.
HEX: Argh.
ACE: Hex.
HEX: It's all over me. I can't move.
ACE: Take my hand. Urgh. Other hand.
DOCTOR: (distant) Hurry up. Looks like it's building up for another one.

HEX: Ah! I'm covered in s...

HEX: That's another fine mess you've got me into.
DOCTOR: Five, four...
ACE: Shut up and drive!
DOCTOR: Three, two... oh.
ACE: + HEX: Doors.
DOCTOR: Good trip, you two?
HEX: You're joking, aren't ya? Look at the state of me.
DOCTOR: I don't know. Maybe your trousers look better shiny.
HEX: They're not shiny. They're muc'd.
ACE: Get away from me. You need a shower.
HEX: I need a really big hanky. I think I've got to go and blow my pants.

ACE: Third left.

ACE: Er...

ACE: You're putting me on the spot. Have you got any brochures?
DOCTOR: This is a Time and Space machine, not a travel agent's. Of course I don't have any...
HEX: Hey, what are all these brochures doing in the bog?
ACE: Brochures.
DOCTOR: Ah. I was wondering what had happened to those. They must have been misplaced when the Tardis architecture last reconfigured itself.
ACE: Must have.
HEX: Hey! The Death Well of Mindar. Is that a ride?
DOCTOR: No. It's a death well. Try one without a screaming face on the front. They're more humanoid friendly.
ACE: The Eye Boiling Vat of Pain at Fringan. Hex?
HEX: Ah, I dunno. Something about the name's putting me off. Here you are, here's one. The Festival of the Twin Moons of Tuin.
DOCTOR: Ah, The Festival of the Twin Moons of Tuin. That takes me back.
HEX: Well , what is it?
DOCTOR: Well, it's a festival, of the planet Tuin, and it involves the twin moons.
ACE: I think we got that, Doctor.
HEX: Er, yeah. Can you be a bit more specific?
DOCTOR: The Festival of the Twin Moons of Tuin takes place once every five hundred Tuin years, which is approximately...
ACE: Five hundred Earth years?
DOCTOR: Approximately. It's a celebration of all the good aspects of the planet Tuin, and it takes the form of a week-long party with music and dancing.
HEX: Well, that sounds all right. Music and dancing. Like Glastonbury. Will there be a beer tent?
DOCTOR: Oh, almost certainly. The planet Tuin has often been referred to as the Brewery of the Galaxy.
HEX: Ah, so there might be the odd lager knocking about.
DOCTOR: Read that.
HEX: The beer houses of Tuin boast as many as fourteen hundred varieties of ale. Great, what are we waiting for? Let's go.
ACE: Hang on! I want a break, not a booze-up.
DOCTOR: Next paragraph?
ACE: Er, the Festival of Tuin is also noted for its emphasis on peace and relaxation. Spas fully-equipped with... Wow! All right then, I'm sold.
DOCTOR: Very well. I suppose the Tardis could use an airing.
HEX: Hurrah! Planet Ale, here we come!
DOCTOR: Mind you, if you want beer, The Eye Boiling Vat of Pain at Fringan does a very nice pint.
HEX: Yeah, but with a name like that, it's got to be part of a chain.
ACE: Bit bleak. You're sure this is Tuin?
DOCTOR: Yes. It does seem somewhat overcast.
HEX: Yeah, but there's not a cloud in the sky.
DOCTOR: Well observed, Master Hex. So, we must be overcast by... Ah!
HEX: That massive great big enormous huge giant pillar behind us?
ACE: The one that's as tall as the Empire State Building and twice as wide? You reckon?
HEX: Caught your eye too, did it?
DOCTOR: (distant) Come on!
HEX: What does he mean, come on? Hurry up, it's lunch time, or...
ACE: Or, follow me, I've had an idea and I'm too brainy to explain it to you, then later something awful will happen and he'll apologise for not mentioning it earlier.
HEX: Hmm. Sounds like fun.
ACE: What, unpleasantness, fear, boredom, danger and weird alien creatures sounds like fun?
HEX: Yeah. It's not that different to [?7], really.
DOCTOR: (distant) I've found something!
ACE: Here we go. He's found something. Where are you?
DOCTOR: (distant) Over the ridge.
HEX: What ridge? Ah!
ACE: That ridge. Hey. Are those graves?
HEX: Nah. There's miles and miles of them. The whole planet'd have to be a graveyard.
DOCTOR: You know, I think this whole planet is a graveyard.
ACE: Great.
ACE: RI COMPUTER 1: (male) Alert. Sensors detect super space chatter on [??] surface.
ACE: RI COMPUTER 2: (female) Recount chatter.
ACE: RI COMPUTER 1: Recounting.
DOCTOR: [OC]: You know, I think this whole planet is a graveyard.
DOCTOR: RI COMPUTER 2: These are not Ri.
DOCTOR: RI COMPUTER 1: Then they must be Ir.
DOCTOR: RI COMPUTER 2: Follicle count says these are not Ir.
DOCTOR: RI COMPUTER 1: Then they must be Ir spies.
DOCTOR: RI COMPUTER 1 + RI COMPUTER 2: And Ir must be destroyed.
DOCTOR: RI COMPUTER 2: Despatch nearest Ri sentinel.
DOCTOR: RI COMPUTER 1: Nearest Ri Sentinel. Senior Infantry Fighter Ori, from the Second Corps of Those Prepared For Death, Third Battalion, Carrion Of Tomorrow regiment. Brigade of Bones Scattered Across the Boundary of...
DOCTOR: RI COMPUTER 2: Sentinel is adequately locked. Despatching Senior Infantry Fighter Ori. Find the Ir spies. Destroy the Ir. Destroy.
ACE: What's so interesting, Doctor?
DOCTOR: The markings on this pillar. Fascinating.
HEX: It's a mural. They had one outside our community centre, only it got graffiti'd. Nobody found out who did it, but I got the blame.
DOCTOR: Fascinating.
HEX: Maybe if I hadn't have signed it.
ACE: Hex?
HEX: Oh, sorry. Yeah, go on.
DOCTOR: Thank you. This particular mural is ancient. Legends and lore going back thousands of years, and...
ACE: Well, it's a war memorial, isn't it? Look, these blokes here, fighting these blokes here...
DOCTOR: I'm not so sure.
ACE: Doctor, you said this was a place of peace and tranquillity.
HEX: And beer.
DOCTOR: Well, it's peaceful enough now. I'm sorry. Sometimes the Tardis misses its target.
ACE: Sometimes? Doctor, sundials at night are more accurate than the Tardis. Underwater sundials at night are more accurate than the Tardis.
DOCTOR: A tragedy of this scale must have quite a story behind it.
ACE: Just for once I wanted a world without a story, Doctor. Not the past, not the future, just the present.
DOCTOR: Oh, very well. I'll just gather some data here, and then we'll pop back a few thousand years and have a holiday.
ACE: What, here? Knowing what's going to happen to all these people?
DOCTOR: Ace, every world I visit, every civilisation I come across, I go there knowing that one day it'll end. In war or catastrophe or just in the sudden snuffing out of a sun.
HEX: And I thought me Mam could put a downer on a holiday. Look, I'm with Ace. I don't fancy having a break around here.
ACE: Come on Hex, let's go back.
HEX: Right.
DOCTOR: I don't tell them their civilisations are going to end. That'd be rude. I... Oh well. I suppose we could go somewhere nice. Nice. Honestly, humans. Only a planet that's had seven world wars could come up with a concept like nice. The H Bomb and the toasted teacake. Twin poles of Man's achievement. Oh. Ah, now. This is interesting. Placed here to commemorate the glorious dead. Always the same, these things. And the war that shall never end. Oh dear. It would seem that this war is still going on. Bone fields, hops and meadows. Oh dear, oh dear, oh dear, oh dear. Hmm. That's interesting. Ace, I'm busy. I'll join you and Hex in the Tardis in a... Don't poke me with that...
DOCTOR: Gun. Ah. Oh. Hello, I'm the Doctor.
ORI: Spy. Agent of Ir.
DOCTOR: Ah, no, you see, I...
HEX: What?
HEX: + ACE: Was that?
ACE: Trouble. Doctor?
HEX: Where are you? Doctor?
ORI: More Ir.
ACE: Oh no!
HEX: Wow! He's a bit hairy, isn't he?
ACE: Get down!
ACE: Are you okay?
HEX: Yeah, yeah.
HEX: Oi! These are gravestones!
ORI: (spits) Ir graves.
ACE: Don't think he cares. No sign of the Doctor.
HEX: Not unless he's been zapped already.
ACE: What is that thing?
HEX: I'm a nurse, Jim. Not a man who knows what... that thing is. But it's very ginger, and very hairy. So come on, what's our plan?
ACE: We haven't got a plan.
HEX: Why haven't we got a plan?
ACE: Shall we go back and have a meeting? I think there's a conference room somewhere in the Tardis. Maybe we could brainstorm a few ideas. You know, see what we come up with?
ORI: I'm coming to get you.
HEX: Fair point. You know, you're very attractive when you're sarcastic.
ACE: Look, you distract whatever itis, and I'll run in and try to get the Doctor.
HEX: Distract it? With what, me holiday snaps?
ACE: Just do something. Good luck.
HEX: Brilliant. We're ten feet away from Alan the space orang-utan and his great big enormous zappy super- gun, and she wants me to run around waving me arms shouting, chase me, chase me.
ORI: I can smell you, Ir scum.
HEX: Oi! You! Simply Red! Over â€˜ere!
HEX: Missed. Hey, guess what? I snogged your Mum. And she was rubbish!
ACE: Doctor? Doctor.
DOCTOR: Ace.
ACE: Eh? Where are...?
DOCTOR: Here.
ACE: Oh. Where? Oh. You've been digging your own grave again?
DOCTOR: Help me out.
ACE: Oh yeah. I see the problem. They bury their dead ten feet under. Hang on. Oh! If I just... lower myself...
DOCTOR: Careful.
ACE: Just get hold of my foot. Ow!
DOCTOR: Sorry.
ACE: Wrench it out of the socket, why don't you? Oh. Oh!
DOCTOR: The side's giving way.
ACE: Ow!
DOCTOR: Ace ?
ACE: Oh... I'm fine. I think.
DOCTOR: It's all up to Hex now. Where is he?
ACE: Distracting the alien with taunts and sexual innuendo.
DOCTOR: And that's the full extent of your plan?
ACE: Sorry, we couldn't schedule the full brainstorm. Found you though, didn't I?
DOCTOR: True. Ah. Unfortunately, so did our friend. And he's holding his gun to Hex's head.
HEX: Sorry.
ORI: Ir scum. I have you now.
ORI: RI COMPUTER 2: Plasmoid blast detected on Tuin surface.
ORI: RI COMPUTER 1: Recount.
ORI: RI COMPUTER 2: Recounting.
HEX: [OC]: Oi! You! Simply Red! Over 'ere!
HEX: RI COMPUTER 1: Plasmoid blasts suggests presence of Ri infantry.
HEX: RI COMPUTER 2: Low follicle count suggests their enemy is neither Ir nor Ri. Who is their enemy? RI COMPUTER 1: Despatch scout ship to investigate. Glory to Ir.
HEX: RI COMPUTER 2: Glory. Glory.
ORI: Get in.
HEX: Hey!
DOCTOR: Hex, are you...?
HEX: Fine. I'd have just climbed in if you would have asked me nicely. Sorry about that, folks.
ACE: Suppose you did your best.
HEX: I think he got upset when I made a reference to his Auntie Marge, and a tub of margari...
ORI: Be quiet. You are all three prisoners of the army of Ri. We are the true way. We are the only force. We are Ri.
HEX: You're ginger, mate. That's what you are. Ginger all over!
DOCTOR: Hex. It's very unwise to mock the physical appearance of another species.
ACE: Especially with mucus in your hair.
ORI: Silence. Who are you?
DOCTOR: Well, how can we answer that, when you've just told us to be silent?
ORI: You are spies from Ir.
DOCTOR: Oh, please. It's always spies with you people, isn't it? No one's ever a tourist, or lost, or visiting their nephew. No, it's spies every time.
ACE: We're travellers.
HEX: Just passing through. On a visit, like. Any idea where the beer tent is?
ORI: Ha! There have been no visitors here for thousands of years. Tuin is a wasteland, a desert. No life remains on Tuin. Unending war between our moon of Ri, and the enemy moon of Ir, has cursed her sorry surface. There is nothing here but the silent dead.
HEX: I told you we shouldn't have come off-season.
DOCTOR: Look, whatever your name is, we're...
ORI: Senior Infantry Fighter Ori, from the Second Corps of Those Prepared For Death, Third Battalion, Carrion of Tomorrow Regiment, Brigade of Bones Scattered Across The Universe...
DOCTOR: Yes, yes, yes, yes, Ori, yes. We're not here to harm you, and goodness knows, we're not interested in your war. How long did you say it's been going on for?
ORI: Ten thousand years.
DOCTOR: Couldn't you have come up with a better way of spending ten thousand years?
ORI: The hatred between our peoples is fierce and strong.
ACE: Well, it'd be pretty stupid to be at war all this time because you found each other mildly annoying.
DOCTOR: Look what you've done to this planet. A perfectly pleasant planet, in bits.
ORI: War brings with it its own necessities . If our homeworld should perish in our conflict, so be it.
DOCTOR: Your homeworld? I notice you've conveniently failed to blow up your own moon in all of this.
ORI: The moon of Ri has suffered in war. See how its surface is pitted.
DOCTOR: Your moon's still there though, isn't it? And your opponents, the Ir, they've still got their moon, so everybody's happy.
ORI: You are fools. You know nothing of the dispute between our two peoples.
DOCTOR: I'm sure it was all terribly important at the time, but really, isn't it about time you sorted it out?
ACE: Doctor, I'm not sure this is the time to play peacemaker.
DOCTOR: Come on, Ace. These people have been at war for ten thousand years. And over what? Somebody probably misheard somebody say something at a banquet, or dropped a comb in somebody's soup. Any one of a million stupid petty reasons which apparently justified the slaughter of millions of innocent people.
ORI: The people of Ri fired a plague missile at our capital city.
HEX: I gotta say, that is a bit steep.
ORI: We did drop a thousand lava bombs on their capital city first, but we had just cause.
ACE: Doctor.
DOCTOR: What is it?
ACE: That!
IRIT: [OC]: Er... Hello... Testing. (tapping twice) Er... surrender your weapons. Surrender your weapons.
ORI: Never! Die, Ir scum!
ACE: Ori, put that stupid gun down. That's a fully armed battle craft.
ORI: I shall die for Ri.
DOCTOR: I don't think that's wise.
ORI: True. Retreat, retreat, or I shall blast your spies into oblivion.
HEX: Good intervention, Doctor.
IRIT: [OC]: The Ir do not retreat.
ORI: Then watch your agents writhe in the agonies of a slow protracted death.
DOCTOR: Ori, no!
ORI: Die! Die! Die!
HEX: What was that?
ACE: Tractor beam?
DOCTOR: Attractor beam. A beam that attracts us.
HEX: Oh, I get it.
ACE: All right, snarky.
HEX: So we're inside the battle craft, do you think?
ACE: Obviously.
HEX: All right, snarky.
DOCTOR: Which makes these gentlemen the Ir.
IRIT: Surrender your weapons.
DOCTOR: We have no weapons. We come in peace.
IRIT: You do? Ah well, all the same, search them.
ACE: Oi! Tell your boot boys to back off.
DOCTOR: Let's just cooperate, shall we, Ace?
ACE: Just watch it, Baldy.
HEX: Hang on. They're all baldy.
ACE: Oh, blimey. Right Said Fred made it into space.
IRIT: We of the Ir are proud to be hairless. You show signs of redegeneracy. These shabby lank and greasy locks.
HEX: Bit personal. There's nothing lank or greasy about my hair.
ACE: Well, actually...
HEX: Oh right. Snot.
IRIT: Vile.
IRIT: They're clear. No mini-guns, anti-personnel mines.
DOCTOR: Scissors, razor blades, screwdrivers, not us.
IRIT: Excellent. Well now, all that remains is to kill you.
ACE: Sorry?
IRIT: I expect you are. But really, there's no need. It's a painless death, and as we don't believe in an afterlife, you won't be going to Hell.
DOCTOR: Before you do kill us...
HEX: Hey, you're giving in a bit easily, aren't ya? I really would like not to be killed.
ACE: Yeah, me too. Er, me neither.
DOCTOR: Oh, come now. When faced with the inevitable, you really ought to just sit back and accept it.
ACE: Doctor, this isn't a visit to the dentist. They're gonna to kill us.
IRIT: Yes, and we'd like to do it sooner rather than later, if you don't mind.
DOCTOR: Of course. But before you do complete your no doubt completely necessary task...
IRIT: Yes?
DOCTOR: You couldn't tell me, why is it completely necessary?
IRIT: Well, because there's a war on.
DOCTOR: Oh, I see.
IRIT: And it wouldn't be much of a war if we didn't kill anyone, would it?
DOCTOR: I suppose not. Well, thank you for sorting that out.
IRIT: Not at all. It's nice to see such an understanding attitude in a foe. Most of them are so self-centred when it comes to death. Foolish really when a time like... well, like this should be an occasion for composing oneself, not screaming and running around begging for things.
ACE: Begging for things?
IRIT: Things, yes. Mercy, life, that sort of carry-on. Anyway, time moves on and I'd love to talk, but you know how it is.
ACE: Doctor, can you hear...?
DOCTOR: Yes I can. There's one more thing...
IRIT: There always is, but now we really must terminate your existence. Existences. I never get that right.
DOCTOR: Have you noticed that sound?
IRIT: What sound?
ACE: The loud one?
DOCTOR: I believe it's an all-clear, Ace. But I'd like my friend from the Ir to confirm that.
IRIT: Oh, all right. That sound, as I suspect you know, is a signal.
DOCTOR: The signal, in fact.
IRIT: Yes. It's the Sign of Commencement.
DOCTOR: The Sign of Commencement. A giant klaxon created in a brief moment of truce 9500 years ago and now sounded once every five hundred years. It indicates the start of the most important event in the calendar of the Twin Moons of Tuin.
ACE: Could that be the Festival of the Twin Moons of Tuin?
HEX: So the festival's still on? Great! Mine's a pint.
DOCTOR: Not only does the Sign of Commencement signal the start of Tuin's most revered festival - and yes, Hex, opening time - the only occasion in fact where Ir and Ri are briefly at peace. But also... Oh, you tell them.
IRIT: The end of any hostilities for the period of the festival.
ACE: They can't execute us now!
IRIT: As you very well knew. Come, my fellow Ir, we must land on Tuin and prepare the Festival.
HEX: Hey, what about us?
IRIT: Detract them.
HEX: You wha...?
ACE: De-tractor beam. I get it.
DOCTOR: Quite. Detracted back whence we came.
HEX: Hang on. Up there, were you playing for time?
ACE: Oh Hex, duh!
DOCTOR: Having made certain calculations based on the alignment of the Pillar of Remembrance and the positioning of the Moons, it was a simple matter to check my hunch that we had arrived less than an hour before the Sign of Commencement would occur.
HEX: I don't get it. I thought this Festival was out the window, on account of the war and that.
DOCTOR: Oh Hex, this Festival is the only way of ending the war, which is why we're here.
ACE: He's done it again. The whole thing was deliberate from the start. We never were going on holiday, were we? This was never a break. You never got the date wrong.
HEX: You mean you planted those brochures in the Tardis bog?
DOCTOR: What suspicious minds you have.
ORI: Stand still.
HEX: Ah, no. The ginger minger's back.
ORI: The Ir chose not to kill you, I see. Therefore you must be their allies. So I must kill you.
HEX: Clock the klaxon? It's Festival time, mate. You can't kill us.
ACE: Well? Get out of that.
HEX: Is he gonna cry?
ORI: You have shamed me, for I had you at my mercy, and failed to deliver the killing shot.
ACE: Honestly, some aliens.
ORI: I ask only that you accept the hospitality of the Ri.
DOCTOR: I think he's going to buy you a pint, Hex.
HEX: He is? Brilliant! Where's the beer tent, then?
HEX: Cheers, Ori.
ORI: Health to you, and painful bowel diseases to your enemies.
HEX: Hey, you should have this Festival more often. It's all right.
ORI: Ah, once this Festival took place yearly, Hox. People came from Ir and Ri, and the ocean cities of Deep Tuin, to the mountain folk of High Tuin.
HEX: So people lived on Tuin once too? Not just you lot and the Ir?
ORI: Tuin was the world that birthed us. Tuin was our mother, and we its children. When dispute came, Tuin was ravaged, and we and the Ir retreated to our Moons. But still we fight for our murdered mother. Still, Hox, we fight!
HEX: Er, calm down Ori. I was just asking. Hey, and stop calling me Hox. It's Hex.
HEX: Sorry, did I say something funny?
ORI: No, it's just your name.
HEX: And what's wrong with my name?
ORI: Hex. It means something else in my tongue.
HEX: Oh yeah? Like what?
ORI: I shall draw a picture of one in this pool of ale.
HEX: Oh. Oh, fair enough. Yeah, don't call me Hex.
ORI: Never mind, little Hox. Down in one. Three, two, one!
ACE: Hex seems to be well in with that Ori.
DOCTOR: The Ri are people of their word.
ACE: What about the other lot, the Ir?
DOCTOR: So long as the Festival is on, nobody can lay a finger on anyone else.
ACE: Are you sure?
DOCTOR: Ace, this Festival is so old, keeping the peace is virtually encoded in their DNA.
ACE: You seem to know a lot about this place, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Yes, well, one makes a study of these things.
ACE: More than a study. What was that you said back there about ending the war?
DOCTOR: Hmm.
ACE: Doctor? What are you up to?
ORI: Let us drink more ale.
HEX: Good idea! No, no, it's my round. Oh, hang on. Doctor? Doctor, what do we do about dosh?
DOCTOR: I take it the beer is recommending itself to you?
HEX: Hey, it's the business. I am rockin"!
ACE: You sure about that?
HEX: Give it a minute. It's kickinâ€™ in. I'll be well on me way in no time!
DOCTOR: I doubt it, Hex. Since the war, all Tuinese beer has been strictly alcohol free.
HEX: What?
DOCTOR: There's a war on, you know. Now, Ori?
ORI: Doctor.
DOCTOR: I need your help.
ORI: Anything. I shall burn your likeness into my fur. I shall put my fingers into the mouth of a Tooth fish. I...
DOCTOR: I'll bear that in mind, but for now, I just want to meet a priest.
ORI: A priest? You wish to honour the traditions of the Ri?
DOCTOR: Well, partly. But mostly, I want to do what I came here to do.
HEX: Which is what?
DOCTOR: Which is to end this war. It's gone on far too long.
ORI: End the war, Doctor? End millennia of conflict, you?
DOCTOR: Yes, me.
ACE: And how are you going to do that?
DOCTOR: Oh, that's easy. I'm going to get married.

elements.text: [Part Two]
You're going to what?
Anyone we know, Doctor?
Doctor, you insult me.
You have no cause to be insulted.
You offend the ancient ways.
I don't get it. I thought you wanted to end the war, not get married.
The only way to end the war is to get married. That's right, isn't it, Ori?
I er, I don't know what you're talking about.
You're not the only one, mate. I thought I'd come out on the inter-planetary lash. Now, I don't know where I am.
Hex, you've got an excuse. Ori here is dissembling.
I am Ori of the Ri. Lies are alien to us. We speak only truth.
Whoosh.
Oh no, not you again.
Why? This is the Ir's festival too.
Ir scum.
You choose your friends unwisely. I, Irit of the Ir, I say it is truth that is alien to the Ri.
Hey. Was he eavesdropping?
Yes, that's the Ir way. Sly, sly, and devious, and in need of a smiting.
Hey, hey, big fella. Festival, remember?
I don't get it, Doctor. How did you know Ori was lying?
Because he speaks from the mouth of the Ri.
That's enough. The truth is plain to see, isn't it?
Er...
Graves as far as the horizon? Don't say you didn't notice.
Well, yeah. We all saw the graves.
Ir and Ri graves, all together. The dead of both sides, buried top to toe.
Yeah.
I've seen a lot of wars. A lot of ghastly, awful wars.
But have you ever seen one where both sides placed their dead in the very same batch of land?
All of them buried in vast concentric circles orbiting that pillar.
It's not a war memorial, is it?
Then what is it?
I read the murals on the pillar, and I learned that for all Ori's huff and all Irit's puff, their peoples have one thing in common.
+ IRIT: Never!
Oh, they share a common home fold and a common hatred.
That's two things.
Shut up, Hex.
All right, they share a third thing. They share the same belief system.
The faith of the Ir is not the true faith.
(Simultaneous) The faith of the Ri is not the true faith.
Oh, after ten millennia, the odd bits of doctrine will have diverged here and there.
Mostly things to do with hair?
Beliefs half as old would have splintered a hundredfold in the same time frame. Two mortal enemies at war for thousands of years, but they share the same God.

That's weird, that is. I mean, there's people in my street back at home not talking because one of them eats something different one day of the week. But this lot have been scrapping forever, and technically, they can still go to church together?
Exactly. They can still go to church together, and on one day, one vitally important day that only occurs once every few centuries, that's exactly what they do.
The pillar, then? Is that the church you're talking about?
The pillar is just part of the church, Ace, a very small part. No, you're standing in the church. Or rather, on it. The church...
... Is Tuin.
Tuin. Our home.
Tuin. Rent asunder by war for so long that even our foulest enemies agreed that enough was enough.
It is a sacred place now.
And none shall fight here.
But you were fighting here.
+ IRIT: Not all the time.
So, both sides got together and said, Tuin is a holy place that none shall defile. But not all the time. Well, you can't have a sacred place and have a war in it, can you?
Well, they have bank holidays off.
That's what the festival is. The only time the Ir and Ri can't fight. I got that bit.
Itâ€™s slightly more than that. This is the only time that the Ir and Ri can make peace.
Never. I shall die with my hands around the throat of an Ir.
Pah. If it were me, I should spit in your face.
But the war can be stopped, Ace. Hex, help me up on the table. I've an announcement to make.
No!
You must not.
On the contrary, I must. (shouts) Hear me! Ir and Ri, hear me! Hear my words. In the name of the unity of Tuin I offer myself as suitor.
Crowd gasps.
Oh Doctor, I hope you know what you're doing.
I say, let him do it.
[OC]: Hear me, Ir and Ri. (echoes) Hear me! Hear my words. In the name of the unity of Tuin I offer myself as suitor. Suitor. Suitor. I offer myself as suitor.
I hear. I hear his words. He comes. The Dark Husband comes.
You are not one of our people.
You cannot.
They've got a point, Doctor.

Oh, but they're wrong. The Unity of Tuin is not restricted to the peoples of one world. In fact, if I read the pillar correctly, the articles of the Common Faith specifically urges its priests to explore and convert the heathen.
And you're most certainly the heathen.
Quite, Hex.
This is unacceptable. It is a Ri trick. The Ir utterly condemn and denounce the impostor, and were we allowed to, we would disembowel him without mercy.
Aye, and we'd join you.
You would not.
Fair enough.
But you can't. You can't do anything. You know the rules, and you know you must abide by them. I have announced myself as suitor, and I insist you begin the preparations now.
Why...
Wait!
He is... correct. The suitor has declared himself. We have no choice but to accede to the articles of law.
Take him. Hoist him.
Take him to the House of Faith.
Can it be? He comes, he comes. My Bards, awake. The husband comes.
1: (male) Ten thousand years awaitment.
2: (female)Or five score by one hundred.
He comes. He comes. The Husband comes.
The Dark Husband. (laughs)
Hello? Hello? Cor. Joss-sticks.
Hey, look at this.
Gong.
Hey! Are you asking for trouble or what?
No point in providing a gong if you don't want someone to whack it.
Gong hit again.
Shop!
The Doctor, married? What's going on, Ace?
I don't know, but he's really going for it.
And what does it mean, suitor? How does getting married end the war?
Maybe it's like an alliance or something.
Yeah, but who with? Hey, and what about us? Will we have to move out of the Tardis when the Missus moves in?
Don't be stupid. The Doctor's bound to have a plan. I mean... he's bound to, isn't he?
Grinding sounds.
Doctor.
Hey, nice gear. Black suits ya.
What was that about the Tardis, Hex?
Oh, nothing.
I think there's been some confusion. When I nominated myself suitor I didn't mean it in the literal sense. I'm not going to be standing outside Ori's house with a bunch of flowers.
We didn't actually think that.
Ori's a bloke anyway.
No she isn't.
Eh?
So, you're not literally getting married?
Ah.
You are.
You're getting married?
Literally.
Yes.
To a lady?
The cultural norms on Tuin are gender-divided, so yes, I presume I'm getting married to a lady.
I don't believe this.
It's really quite simple. You see, it's the only way to stop the war.
Yeah, you said that, but...
They're coming for me. Both of you, please. You have to trust me.
Doctor.
Ori and Irit. Hello.
I am Irit of the Ir.
And I am Ori of the Ri!
As the first members of our respective peoples to have made contact with the heathen...
With the suitor.
Yes, suitor. We're bound by the Common Faith to act as representatives of each of our Moons.
Two best men, right?
Hex was hoping you'd ask him, Doctor.
Until the hour of the wedding, we shall protect the suitor against all foes.
There is only one foe here.
Silence, bald Irit scum.
Do not call me bald, you comb's nightmare.
Please. Please finish your... thing you were saying.
And... And to instruct his companions in the relevant rituals of the Common Faith.
What?
Oh yes. You are to be my companions.
I hope this means we just get to hang around and look cool.
I will take one of you, and the... Ir will take the other, and we will prepare you in the ways of our peoples, So you... SO yOu...
So you don't ruin the most important ceremony in the history of our planet through your own ignorance.
Oh, cheers.
Oh, come on, Doctor. I'm not going back to Sunday School, not even for you.
No. Ace, you go with the... Who's Ace going with?
I shall take care of her. Come heathen, and learn the ways of the Ir. Garmenting, garlanding and fasting.
T'rrific.
The Ir side of the ritual is aesthetic and pure.
I haven't got to do any of that, have I? Ori? Mate?
The Ri respect the Common Faith, but we also like beer. And now wedding is announced, we can get out the good stuff.
All right!
Doctor!
It's nothing too unpleasant, Ace. These people, this planet, deserves an end to this stupid mess. Thousands of years of conflict all based on some moment of pig-headedness.
Yeah, they're not the only pig-headed ones round here.
It's just a ritual.
But how does it end the war?
(sotto) That's what I intend to find out.
(sotto) You mean you don't know? But what...?
Come, supplicant. You will stay in our craft.
I'm not a flaming supplicant. (sighs) All right, I'm coming.
That's the spirit, Ace.
Don't fast too hard. See you then, Doctor. Ori and me have some religious education to be getting on with.
So I think have I.
The suitor must spend some time in the Cellar of Lonely Contemplation.
How much time?
I'll know when I've contemplated long enough, apparently.
Shuttle clunking back and forth across a loom.
Companion Ace, you must weave, weave.
One, I don't know how to porking weave, and two, I don't want to porking weave. What happened to the religious education?
This is religious education. By weaving, you learn how the world was woven.
Yeah. Worlds aren't woven, Irit.
lf they are not woven from the glitter of stars, from the thread of comets, from the warp and weft of supernovae, how are they made?
Oh well, when you put it like that... Hey, can I ask a question?
A religious one, yes.
What exactly happens when this wedding takes place?
It is a wonderful thing.
Yes. And...?
Ah... ah well... er... 1, I, I don't exactly know. You see, this event...
The wedding, yeah?
It has never been performed.
In your lifetime, you mean?
In anyone's lifetime. To be honest, we're not really sure what it's for.
Right. (sighs) One more thing. Who's he marrying?
Excuse me?
The Doctor. Whoâ€™s he marrying?
Oh, that's easy. The Wife.
Well, who else would he be marrying?
No. No, no, no, no. The Wife. The Shining Wife.
Oh. And who or what is the Shining Wife?
Ah. Now, that is an entirely different question.
What do you mean, it's a different question? Ori?
What I say, Hox, when you ask, who will the Doctor marry, the answer is the Wife, simple. But when you ask, who is the Wife...
The Shining Wife?
The Shining Wife. You ask not a simple question, but something that is at the heart of our faith.
Your shared faith.
Stop mentioning that. It's very poor manners.
Yeah, and so is mopping up beer with your fur.
The identity of the Shining Wife is one of the most obscure mysteries of our religion. What does she represent? How can a mere mortal marry such a figure?
Any ideas?

Huh. (laughs) We are the Ri. We do not go in for ideas. We like fighting and drinking and food. And the Ir, all their posturing and weaving, do not know either. No, the truth is no longer held in the minds of the people of the twin moons of Tuin.
It's going to be an interesting do then, eh? With nobody knowing anything.
Your friend the Doctor seems to think he knows something.
You think? Fifteen minutes in the Cellar of Lonely Contemplation? He'll be climbing the walls by now.

Ah! No secret passages in the walls, then. Hmm. What's it for, this lonely contemplation? I said, what's it for! Unless this whole cellar is a convenient place to dump me while I'm being watched? Is that it? Watched? Probed? Surveyed from afar? Show yourself!
He is intelligent.
1: Cleverer than seventy four score Ir.
2: With a thinking brain so sharp and clear.
Be quiet.

Well, if you're not going to talk to me, I'm going to talk at you. Now, about this manual I've been handed. Instructions for a husband of Tuin in the ways and wherefores of the marriage ritual. You do realise half the pages are missing? And the half that remain, well , they don't make much sense at all, so far as I can make out. Eh? Ah, yes. The suitor. Which would be me. Demands that the wedding ceremony take place. Well, I've done that. I learned that much from the pillar. Then it says, he endures a period of lonely contemplation before he takes the hand of the Shining Wife. Whomsoever she might be. And then he becomes the Dark Husband.
The Dark Husband?
The Dark Husband. That is the name the suitor takes at the wedding of Tuin.
Sounds a bit gloomy.
Gloomy? The fate of two Moons hang in the balance.
I still don't see how.
Is it not obvious?
No, that's why I said, I still don't see how.
Think, child. Two moons?
Two partners. Ir and Ri. Bride and groom.
But I still don't get it. Are you saying that Ir is like the groom's family, and Ri are the bride's? Cos that would be a heck of a punch-up if there's was too much booze at the wedding.
It is simple. Each partner represents one of the two moons. Ir and Ri. A bride and groom. Groom and bride. Shining Wife, and Dark Husband.
Sort of taking sides, then? So which one is the Doctor?

So, I'm the Dark Husband, am I? Well. I could hardly be the Shining Wife. Not in this regeneration at least. Now then. Only through the union of the Dark Husband - me - and the Shining Wife can the unity of Tuin be created. Meaning I presume that everyone gets together, sees they're all the same and ends this stupid war. Am I correct? I said, am I correct?
Blasphemy! Blasphemy!
Correct him, my Bards, as he requests. Detract.
Well now, hello. Detractor beam, I take it? But where exactly did you two detract from?
1: Who has summoned the Bards of Tuin?
You're made of stone. Very old warm stone. Interesting.
2: Who has summoned the Bards of Tuin? Press One for Student, Two for Academic, Three for Tourist, and Four to go back to the start.
Well, I might be all three. Press where?
1: Press One for Student, Two for Academic, Three for Tourist...
No. I see it now. On your forehead. Student, I think. Does it hurt, rotating your head like that?
We are the Bards of Tuin.
2: We are the recorded souls and memories of the great verse men of Tuin's history.
1: In us are stored the chronicles and law of the people of Tuin.
2: To skip introduction, press One.
Ah! You're some kind of data store, and you must be a back-up disc, yes?
1: Ask us what you will, o Student.
I shall. Tell me, o Bards, about the wedding of Tuin.
2: We Bards shall sing to you.
1: The Wedding Song of Tuin.
If you feel you must.
.2 For ninety hundred years as Tuin spread its wings, Tuin's priests determined this, to protect her people near and far. Fame should they fall from Tuin's ways, and so great council met...
There's no fast forward, I suppose?
JiFive hundred knights of Tuin gathered yon, and each then gave their name. Cleb, Urctus and Melmahay, Jinto, Danto, Renco, Blass...
Not all five hundred. I mean, couldn't you just skip forward a bit?
I don't know, Ori, it's confusing the pants off me. And you don't seem too clear either.
It is a rare and sacred thing, the wedding of Tuin, and you should be privileged to witness it.
Well, it's something to tell people, isn't it? It beats your average registry office do.
And now... my Vigil of Decoy is over. Time for me to go.
Well - Vigil of Decoy? You what?
You'll find out. Hox. You may not follow me.
You must be joking. If this is something to do with the wedding...
No! Friend you may be, but friends may still suffer the death of the 101 new-born Bergils.
Bergils?
It's like... imagine a... Well, anyway, they've got teeth and a sort of... Oh, never mind.
Ori? Ori? Wait!
What do you mean, decoy? What's going on?
It is part of the ceremony, and it is none of your concern.
Course it's my concern! And whatever it is, it's got to be more interesting than weaving.
Ir Command. Detract companion Ace.
Oh no you don't...!
J And knights they were two score and seventeen came forth from...
DOCTOR speaks over their singing.
Fast forward. Of course. Sorry about this. Your necks might ache a bit.
Stone scraping.
JJ The purple and the...
And this. Continue, Bards.
JJ For purpose so has the Wedding of Tuin, and purpose grand design.
That's more like it.
3 And this is all the purpose be...
No. That is enough. I have changed my mind. Retract. Retract the Bards.
No, no, no! Don't you dare retract. Just as it's getting interesting. Gone. I suppose you think that's funny! I said, I suppose you think that's funny.
Door opens.

Ori. Irit. Have you seen those Bards? They just popped out of nowhere. Fantastically useful folklore source, if a fraction opaque in the telling. Ori, Irit. No-one said anything about shooting the groom. Ah! (thud)
The Vigil of Decoy has ended.
Yay! Verily! And... all that.
Oi, mush. Yeah, you with the go faster stripes. Gonna let me through or what?
Ace! Ace!
Hex? Over here!
I can't get to ya. There's too many people.
What's going on? Where's your girlfriend?
She's not... Are you winding me up?
Would I?
Yes.
So?
Disappeared.
Hmph!
Vigil of Decoy, she said.
That's funny. That's just what Irit... Hey, is that a black eye?
She went off and left me with the tab. The bartender wouldn't take plastic, so...
You're so funny. Poor little Hex.
Yeah well, when I see her again, I'm going to give her a piece of my mind.
What was that, Hox?
Ori. You're back.
Poor little Hox, I'm so sorry.
You want to get a steak on that.
What did she say?
Doesn't matter.

You want to get a steak on that. I shall see to it later. But first... Clear the way! Clear away, scum! For I am Senior Infantry Fighter Ori, Second Corps of Those Prepared For Death, Third Battalion Carrion of Tomorrow Regiment. And I eat Ir like you for breakfast! There. We can see now.
That's not all she'll be eating for breakfast, Hox.
Oh, give over. What are you here to see, Ori?
This is an important time. The Moment of Devotion approaches.
Ah. I thought a band was coming on stage.
Five million years from Earth, I bet the Stones are still going.
We have our suitor. Your friend, the Doctor.
The Dark Husband, yeah.
Ah, so you were paying attention. Now, we require a bride.
The Shining Wife.
So begins the process of finding her.
And how do you go about that?
He means, do you have an actual method for finding her? Or is it, you know, random?
The records of our people are very clear on this matter.
That makes a change.
The choosing of the Shining Wife is one of the most solemn events referred to in the Books of the Common Faith. While it has never been performed in living memory...
If at all.
It is a ritual whose details must be followed to the letter.
Yeah, but what details?
Microphone feedback.
Quiet. The choosing is about to begin.
[PA]: Hello. Er - testing , testing. Hello. Anem. People of Tuin, once past, now present, always future.
Hey, it's Irit.
Do Ruby Tuesday!
[PA]: Huh? Oh, sorry? Oh well. Er, a suitor has advanced at this, the Festival of the Twin Moons.
Cheering.

[PA]: And thus begins the wedding of Tuin. The ceremony that defines us, that forces Ir and Ri to unite. (mutters something) To unite and become congregation for the wedding. And so, with the suitor self-elected, and congregation gathered, all that remains is to find the bride.
Find the bride!
Call and response. They're going to get the lighters out any minute!
Shh!
[PA]: Find the Shining Wife, she who is brave, she who is without terror, she who will save the Dark Husband.
Cheering. The Doctor speaks through a gag.
But that's the Doctor. What was he saying?
Burn him. Burn him.
Ori?
Shush! This is the good bit.
What's that they're shouting?
Burn the Husband. Burn him!
I do not like the sound of this.
[PA]: Bind him to the Stake of Decision.
Out of my way, please.
[PA]: What's that, Husband? What's at stake here is you!
Fire ignites.
[PA]: The garb of fire surrounds the Dark Husband.
(muffled) Please! Let me be!
Hex, they're going to burn him alive!
This isn't a wedding. Oh my God, it's a sacrifice. Stop it! Stop it now!

parts.searchable_dialogue:
ACE: You're going to what?
HEX: Anyone we know, Doctor?
ORI: Doctor, you insult me.
DOCTOR: You have no cause to be insulted.
ORI: You offend the ancient ways.
ACE: I don't get it. I thought you wanted to end the war, not get married.
DOCTOR: The only way to end the war is to get married. That's right, isn't it, Ori?
ORI: I er, I don't know what you're talking about.
HEX: You're not the only one, mate. I thought I'd come out on the inter-planetary lash. Now, I don't know where I am.
DOCTOR: Hex, you've got an excuse. Ori here is dissembling.
ORI: I am Ori of the Ri. Lies are alien to us. We speak only truth.
ACE: Oh no, not you again.
IRIT: Why? This is the Ir's festival too.
ORI: Ir scum.
IRIT: You choose your friends unwisely. I, Irit of the Ir, I say it is truth that is alien to the Ri.
HEX: Hey. Was he eavesdropping?
ORI: Yes, that's the Ir way. Sly, sly, and devious, and in need of a smiting.
HEX: Hey, hey, big fella. Festival, remember?
ACE: I don't get it, Doctor. How did you know Ori was lying?
IRIT: Because he speaks from the mouth of the Ri.
DOCTOR: That's enough. The truth is plain to see, isn't it?
HEX: Er...
DOCTOR: Graves as far as the horizon? Don't say you didn't notice.
HEX: Well, yeah. We all saw the graves.
DOCTOR: Ir and Ri graves, all together. The dead of both sides, buried top to toe.
ACE: Yeah.
DOCTOR: I've seen a lot of wars. A lot of ghastly, awful wars.
ACE: But have you ever seen one where both sides placed their dead in the very same batch of land?
DOCTOR: All of them buried in vast concentric circles orbiting that pillar.
ACE: It's not a war memorial, is it?
HEX: Then what is it?
DOCTOR: I read the murals on the pillar, and I learned that for all Ori's huff and all Irit's puff, their peoples have one thing in common.
ORI: + IRIT: Never!
DOCTOR: Oh, they share a common home fold and a common hatred.
HEX: That's two things.
ACE: Shut up, Hex.
DOCTOR: All right, they share a third thing. They share the same belief system.
ORI: The faith of the Ir is not the true faith.
IRIT: (Simultaneous) The faith of the Ri is not the true faith.
DOCTOR: Oh, after ten millennia, the odd bits of doctrine will have diverged here and there.
ACE: Mostly things to do with hair?
DOCTOR: Beliefs half as old would have splintered a hundredfold in the same time frame. Two mortal enemies at war for thousands of years, but they share the same God.
HEX: That's weird, that is. I mean, there's people in my street back at home not talking because one of them eats something different one day of the week. But this lot have been scrapping forever, and technically, they can still go to church together?
DOCTOR: Exactly. They can still go to church together, and on one day, one vitally important day that only occurs once every few centuries, that's exactly what they do.
ACE: The pillar, then? Is that the church you're talking about?
DOCTOR: The pillar is just part of the church, Ace, a very small part. No, you're standing in the church. Or rather, on it. The church...
HEX: ... Is Tuin.
ORI: Tuin. Our home.
IRIT: Tuin. Rent asunder by war for so long that even our foulest enemies agreed that enough was enough.
ORI: It is a sacred place now.
IRIT: And none shall fight here.
ACE: But you were fighting here.
ORI: + IRIT: Not all the time.
DOCTOR: So, both sides got together and said, Tuin is a holy place that none shall defile. But not all the time. Well, you can't have a sacred place and have a war in it, can you?
HEX: Well, they have bank holidays off.
ACE: That's what the festival is. The only time the Ir and Ri can't fight. I got that bit.
DOCTOR: Itâ€™s slightly more than that. This is the only time that the Ir and Ri can make peace.
ORI: Never. I shall die with my hands around the throat of an Ir.
IRIT: Pah. If it were me, I should spit in your face.
DOCTOR: But the war can be stopped, Ace. Hex, help me up on the table. I've an announcement to make.
ORI: No!
IRIT: You must not.
DOCTOR: On the contrary, I must. (shouts) Hear me! Ir and Ri, hear me! Hear my words. In the name of the unity of Tuin I offer myself as suitor.
ACE: Oh Doctor, I hope you know what you're doing.
IR: I say, let him do it.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Hear me, Ir and Ri. (echoes) Hear me! Hear my words. In the name of the unity of Tuin I offer myself as suitor. Suitor. Suitor. I offer myself as suitor.
TUIN: I hear. I hear his words. He comes. The Dark Husband comes.
ORI: You are not one of our people.
IRIT: You cannot.
ACE: They've got a point, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Oh, but they're wrong. The Unity of Tuin is not restricted to the peoples of one world. In fact, if I read the pillar correctly, the articles of the Common Faith specifically urges its priests to explore and convert the heathen.
HEX: And you're most certainly the heathen.
DOCTOR: Quite, Hex.
IRIT: This is unacceptable. It is a Ri trick. The Ir utterly condemn and denounce the impostor, and were we allowed to, we would disembowel him without mercy.
ORI: Aye, and we'd join you.
IRIT: You would not.
ORI: Fair enough.
DOCTOR: But you can't. You can't do anything. You know the rules, and you know you must abide by them. I have announced myself as suitor, and I insist you begin the preparations now.
IRIT: Why...
ORI: Wait!
IRIT: He is... correct. The suitor has declared himself. We have no choice but to accede to the articles of law.
ORI: Take him. Hoist him.
IRIT: Take him to the House of Faith.
TUIN: Can it be? He comes, he comes. My Bards, awake. The husband comes.
BARD: 1: (male) Ten thousand years awaitment.
BARD: 2: (female)Or five score by one hundred.
BARDS: He comes. He comes. The Husband comes.
TUIN: The Dark Husband. (laughs)
HEX: Hello? Hello? Cor. Joss-sticks.
ACE: Hey, look at this.
HEX: Hey! Are you asking for trouble or what?
ACE: No point in providing a gong if you don't want someone to whack it.
ACE: Shop!
HEX: The Doctor, married? What's going on, Ace?
ACE: I don't know, but he's really going for it.
HEX: And what does it mean, suitor? How does getting married end the war?
ACE: Maybe it's like an alliance or something.
HEX: Yeah, but who with? Hey, and what about us? Will we have to move out of the Tardis when the Missus moves in?
ACE: Don't be stupid. The Doctor's bound to have a plan. I mean... he's bound to, isn't he?
ACE: Doctor.
HEX: Hey, nice gear. Black suits ya.
DOCTOR: What was that about the Tardis, Hex?
ACE: Oh, nothing.
DOCTOR: I think there's been some confusion. When I nominated myself suitor I didn't mean it in the literal sense. I'm not going to be standing outside Ori's house with a bunch of flowers.
ACE: We didn't actually think that.
HEX: Ori's a bloke anyway.
DOCTOR: No she isn't.
HEX: Eh?
ACE: So, you're not literally getting married?
DOCTOR: Ah.
ACE: You are.
HEX: You're getting married?
ACE: Literally.
DOCTOR: Yes.
HEX: To a lady?
DOCTOR: The cultural norms on Tuin are gender-divided, so yes, I presume I'm getting married to a lady.
ACE: I don't believe this.
DOCTOR: It's really quite simple. You see, it's the only way to stop the war.
HEX: Yeah, you said that, but...
DOCTOR: They're coming for me. Both of you, please. You have to trust me.
ACE: Doctor.
DOCTOR: Ori and Irit. Hello.
IRIT: I am Irit of the Ir.
ORI: And I am Ori of the Ri!
IRIT: As the first members of our respective peoples to have made contact with the heathen...
ORI: With the suitor.
IRIT: Yes, suitor. We're bound by the Common Faith to act as representatives of each of our Moons.
HEX: Two best men, right?
ACE: Hex was hoping you'd ask him, Doctor.
ORI: Until the hour of the wedding, we shall protect the suitor against all foes.
IRIT: There is only one foe here.
ORI: Silence, bald Irit scum.
IRIT: Do not call me bald, you comb's nightmare.
DOCTOR: Please. Please finish your... thing you were saying.
IRIT: And... And to instruct his companions in the relevant rituals of the Common Faith.
ACE: What?
DOCTOR: Oh yes. You are to be my companions.
HEX: I hope this means we just get to hang around and look cool.
ORI: I will take one of you, and the... Ir will take the other, and we will prepare you in the ways of our peoples, So you... SO yOu...
IRIT: So you don't ruin the most important ceremony in the history of our planet through your own ignorance.
ACE: Oh, cheers.
HEX: Oh, come on, Doctor. I'm not going back to Sunday School, not even for you.
DOCTOR: No. Ace, you go with the... Who's Ace going with?
IRIT: I shall take care of her. Come heathen, and learn the ways of the Ir. Garmenting, garlanding and fasting.
ACE: T'rrific.
IRIT: The Ir side of the ritual is aesthetic and pure.
HEX: I haven't got to do any of that, have I? Ori? Mate?
ORI: The Ri respect the Common Faith, but we also like beer. And now wedding is announced, we can get out the good stuff.
HEX: All right!
ACE: Doctor!
DOCTOR: It's nothing too unpleasant, Ace. These people, this planet, deserves an end to this stupid mess. Thousands of years of conflict all based on some moment of pig-headedness.
ACE: Yeah, they're not the only pig-headed ones round here.
DOCTOR: It's just a ritual.
ACE: But how does it end the war?
DOCTOR: (sotto) That's what I intend to find out.
ACE: (sotto) You mean you don't know? But what...?
IRIT: Come, supplicant. You will stay in our craft.
ACE: I'm not a flaming supplicant. (sighs) All right, I'm coming.
DOCTOR: That's the spirit, Ace.
HEX: Don't fast too hard. See you then, Doctor. Ori and me have some religious education to be getting on with.
DOCTOR: So I think have I.
ORI: The suitor must spend some time in the Cellar of Lonely Contemplation.
HEX: How much time?
DOCTOR: I'll know when I've contemplated long enough, apparently.
IRIT: Companion Ace, you must weave, weave.
ACE: One, I don't know how to porking weave, and two, I don't want to porking weave. What happened to the religious education?
IRIT: This is religious education. By weaving, you learn how the world was woven.
ACE: Yeah. Worlds aren't woven, Irit.
IRIT: lf they are not woven from the glitter of stars, from the thread of comets, from the warp and weft of supernovae, how are they made?
ACE: Oh well, when you put it like that... Hey, can I ask a question?
