HEX: Well - Vigil of Decoy? You what?
ORI: You'll find out. Hox. You may not follow me.
HEX: You must be joking. If this is something to do with the wedding...
ORI: No! Friend you may be, but friends may still suffer the death of the 101 new-born Bergils.
HEX: Bergils?
ORI: It's like... imagine a... Well, anyway, they've got teeth and a sort of... Oh, never mind.
HEX: Ori? Ori? Wait!
ACE: What do you mean, decoy? What's going on?
IRIT: It is part of the ceremony, and it is none of your concern.
ACE: Course it's my concern! And whatever it is, it's got to be more interesting than weaving.
IRIT: Ir Command. Detract companion Ace.
ACE: Oh no you don't...!
BARDS: J And knights they were two score and seventeen came forth from...
DOCTOR: Fast forward. Of course. Sorry about this. Your necks might ache a bit.
BARDS: JJ The purple and the...
DOCTOR: And this. Continue, Bards.
BARDS: JJ For purpose so has the Wedding of Tuin, and purpose grand design.
DOCTOR: That's more like it.
BARDS: 3 And this is all the purpose be...
TUIN: No. That is enough. I have changed my mind. Retract. Retract the Bards.
DOCTOR: No, no, no! Don't you dare retract. Just as it's getting interesting. Gone. I suppose you think that's funny! I said, I suppose you think that's funny.
DOCTOR: Ori. Irit. Have you seen those Bards? They just popped out of nowhere. Fantastically useful folklore source, if a fraction opaque in the telling. Ori, Irit. No-one said anything about shooting the groom. Ah! (thud)
IRIT: The Vigil of Decoy has ended.
ORI: Yay! Verily! And... all that.
ACE: Oi, mush. Yeah, you with the go faster stripes. Gonna let me through or what?
HEX: Ace! Ace!
ACE: Hex? Over here!
HEX: I can't get to ya. There's too many people.
ACE: What's going on? Where's your girlfriend?
HEX: She's not... Are you winding me up?
ACE: Would I?
HEX: Yes.
ACE: So?
HEX: Disappeared.
ACE: Hmph!
HEX: Vigil of Decoy, she said.
ACE: That's funny. That's just what Irit... Hey, is that a black eye?
HEX: She went off and left me with the tab. The bartender wouldn't take plastic, so...
ACE: You're so funny. Poor little Hex.
HEX: Yeah well, when I see her again, I'm going to give her a piece of my mind.
ORI: What was that, Hox?
HEX: Ori. You're back.
ORI: Poor little Hox, I'm so sorry.
ACE: You want to get a steak on that.
ORI: What did she say?
HEX: Doesn't matter.
ORI: You want to get a steak on that. I shall see to it later. But first... Clear the way! Clear away, scum! For I am Senior Infantry Fighter Ori, Second Corps of Those Prepared For Death, Third Battalion Carrion of Tomorrow Regiment. And I eat Ir like you for breakfast! There. We can see now.
ACE: That's not all she'll be eating for breakfast, Hox.
HEX: Oh, give over. What are you here to see, Ori?
ORI: This is an important time. The Moment of Devotion approaches.
HEX: Ah. I thought a band was coming on stage.
ACE: Five million years from Earth, I bet the Stones are still going.
ORI: We have our suitor. Your friend, the Doctor.
HEX: The Dark Husband, yeah.
ORI: Ah, so you were paying attention. Now, we require a bride.
ACE: The Shining Wife.
ORI: So begins the process of finding her.
HEX: And how do you go about that?
ACE: He means, do you have an actual method for finding her? Or is it, you know, random?
ORI: The records of our people are very clear on this matter.
HEX: That makes a change.
ORI: The choosing of the Shining Wife is one of the most solemn events referred to in the Books of the Common Faith. While it has never been performed in living memory...
ACE: If at all.
ORI: It is a ritual whose details must be followed to the letter.
HEX: Yeah, but what details?
ORI: Quiet. The choosing is about to begin.
IRIT: [PA]: Hello. Er - testing , testing. Hello. Anem. People of Tuin, once past, now present, always future.
HEX: Hey, it's Irit.
ACE: Do Ruby Tuesday!
IRIT: [PA]: Huh? Oh, sorry? Oh well. Er, a suitor has advanced at this, the Festival of the Twin Moons.
IRIT: [PA]: And thus begins the wedding of Tuin. The ceremony that defines us, that forces Ir and Ri to unite. (mutters something) To unite and become congregation for the wedding. And so, with the suitor self-elected, and congregation gathered, all that remains is to find the bride.
CROWD: Find the bride!
HEX: Call and response. They're going to get the lighters out any minute!
ACE: Shh!
IRIT: [PA]: Find the Shining Wife, she who is brave, she who is without terror, she who will save the Dark Husband.
ACE: But that's the Doctor. What was he saying?
CROWD: Burn him. Burn him.
HEX: Ori?
ORI: Shush! This is the good bit.
ACE: What's that they're shouting?
CROWD: Burn the Husband. Burn him!
HEX: I do not like the sound of this.
IRIT: [PA]: Bind him to the Stake of Decision.
ACE: Out of my way, please.
IRIT: [PA]: What's that, Husband? What's at stake here is you!
IRIT: [PA]: The garb of fire surrounds the Dark Husband.
DOCTOR: (muffled) Please! Let me be!
ACE: Hex, they're going to burn him alive!
HEX: This isn't a wedding. Oh my God, it's a sacrifice. Stop it! Stop it now!

elements.text: [Part Three]
The chant continues, then changes:
One can save him.
[PA]: One can save him.
One can save him.
We've got to do something.
Oh no, you don't, Hox.
Get off me, Ori!
Man shall not move. Companion Ace, you may restore life if you wish.
[PA]: One can save him.
One can save him.
Ori!
Great blond pillock...
[PA]: One can save him.
One can save him.
Help me up.
You go, girl. Surf that crowd.
[PA]: One shall save him.
Save him, save him, save him...
[PA]: Carry her. Carry her across.
It's all right, Doctor! I'm coming.
(muffled) Ace, no! Stop!
Quiet, Husband. One shall save him.
Doctor! Doctor, hold on!
(muffled) Ace! Ace, it's all right!
Do you think I'm going to let you do your Joan Of Arc impression? How...?
Take this axe, companion Ace.
Cheers. Nutter.
ACE yells, DOCTOR yells to her as though gagged, axe cutting ropes.
Hang on. It's cold. The fire. It's cold.
One has saved him.
Cheers.
It's all right, Doctor. I've got you. The fire's cold. It's all a trick.
Behold the Wife.
The Shining Wife.
Do what?
(mumbling) I said... (normal) Ace, you idiot.
Behold. Behold the Shining Wife.
Oh, that's another fine mess I've gotten myself into.
Door closes.
Well, how was I supposed to know it was all a trick?
You played right into their hands.
Oh, come on, Doctor. Ace wasn't to know. Everyone there believed it was real. I mean, cold fire. How do they do that?
Oh, it's the most basic of chemical illusions.
It was a trap, wasn't it? That's what all the Vigil of Decoy bit was about.
Oh, they didn't want one of their lot being the Shining Wife or whatever it is, so they let Ace step in.
Absolutely. Let the newcomers do the dirty work. We're expendable.
Except the cold fire wouldn't have hurt anyone.
Which means...?
Er...
The nasty part is yet to come.
Precisely.
What nasty part?
That is the question.
Gong sounds.
Silence! The ritual is complete. The choice has been made.
Knock it off. No one here is in the mood.
The brave one has revealed herself. She who stands above all her kind. In her decision, she makes her choice.
Choice? I didn't make a choice. I just did what I had to do.
Fitting words, for modesty becomes a wife.
But I don't want to be the Shining Wife.
Mark of the Shining Wife is bravery.
The rituals are very clear.
I'm not brave, and I won't be anyone's wife.
Not even to end ten thousand years of war, death and pain?
We can do that by going through one ritual?
You're crazy, both of ya. You've no idea what's coming next.
Enough. The final night beckons.
Here we go. I've seen what happens on a normal stag night. I can't imagine what they do here.
The final night!
You'd better watch it, Doctor, if you don't want to end up chained to a lamp post in your Y-fronts.
(sighs) Oh, Hex.
In Boulogne. That's all I'm saying.
And what happens on this final night?
Both Ir and Ri must pass the night with the Dark Husband, by the Campfire of Thwarted Regret.
Keeping watch and telling stories.
Hey, I know some stories. There was this fella...
Oh dear.
No. The Husband must come with us. Alone.
Oh!
Hey, put him down, Ori!
Do not try to follow us, little Hox, or...
What? The Bergils again?
Yes. And that make me... sad.
Well - what are we supposed to do till the morning?
(receding) Read the Manual of Instruction.
Where?
On the lectern. There's more to this than meets the eye.
Come.
Door closes.
Bergils?
Don't ask. So, you marrying the Doctor? Wow.
It's just a ritual, Hex. It doesn't mean anything. I want to have a look at this manual.
Oh. It doesn't mean anything. You and him go back a long way, don't you?
And?
And you get on, you know, pretty well. Well, you're sort of... close.
Hex! We're hours from ending thousands of years of war and you want to know if... Oh. I mean, honestly.
Oh! It's all right for you. You're the Shining Wife. He's the Dark Husband, so what am I, eh? The spare part at the wedding?
Well, I'll tell you what. According to the rituals...
Yeah, yeah, the rituals.
Shut up. According to the rituals, the Shining Wife can ask someone to give her away.
What? Like her dad?
No. A friend. Someone close to her. Someone deep in her affections? Someone she can turn to.
I suppose Ori's all right. A bit hairy, but...
No, you fool, I mean you. I want you to give me away.
I know.
And?
Yeah, okay. No big deal. Are you bored now?
This Bergils business.
Yeah?
Can't be anything so bad, can it?
Ah. A nice warm fire. I hope the flames do not distress you, Doctor.
I find your sense of humour much more distressing, Irit.
We have little time for humour in time of war, Doctor.
Ha! Ir were born without a humour gene. They can no more laugh than I can have a bald backside.
It's going to be a long night.
Ale! Ale!
I'll be Mother.
The time to tell the stories of old Tuin has come.
Heed the ballads of the Bards of Tuin.
Oh, are they coming?
Not the actual Bards of Tuin, obviously.
They are long gone, dead these five score thousand years.
Is that a fact. Your ale, Ori.
Foamy! Ah.
And yours, Irit. It's all head, I'm afraid.
Much like the Ir. Ah.
Good health, gentlemen. So, if the ancient Bards can't make it, who's telling the tales?
I shall, for Ri.
And I, for Ir.
All right.
Full five score thousand years ago, come Bards of old.
Oh dear.
I Know. Listen to that accent. So coarse.
Can you do better, shiny-backed scum of Ir?
Ori, friend, time is short, and there are no doubt many tales to tell.
Oh yes.
So how about getting to the heart of the matter?
Please.
Oh. Ah, suppose.
Do your people have any stories on how this wedding came to be?
Oh yes, hundreds. Rhymes and songs and fables.
Something short, that doesn't rhyme.
Oh well, there is one, but it's a tale for children.
I'm all ears. Drink up, Irit.
Hear then, my story. Ah. The Story of the Planet and the Wanderer.
Go on.
The story goes like this. Once upon a time...
Ha.
... there was a Wanderer. Man was he not, nor woman, but only... Wanderer. And the Wanderer came to a barren world and entered it, and the world was no longer barren.
I hate it already.
I'm enjoying it. Who was this Wanderer?
And the Wanderer named the world, and the name was Tuin. And the world named the Wanderer, and the name was Ri-Ir.
Rubbish. The name was Ir-Ri.
Does it matter?
+ IRIT: Yes!

The Wanderer became estranged from the planet. The Wanderer longed to wander again, yet also the Wanderer longed to be with Tuin. And the soul of the Wanderer was divided and stretched and cut, until it became...
Two souls. We have this story too. A superior telling.
Naturally. Drink up.
And those souls being divided, were not able to wander, nor stay with the planet. They became...
Ir and Ri. The moons. Trapped in near-space, unable to leave Tuin's orbit, or to return.
A story for children, and you got it wrong.
I did not.
So how did your people tell it?
In our version, Ir and Ri are the children of the Wanderer, not the Wanderer's spirit. And they are not
poor orphans floating in the sky. They are outcasts because they killed their parents.
Extraordinary.
Yes. And so they were hanged, hanged in the sky. Guilty of killing Mother Tuin, and Father Ir-Ri. Or itâ€™s Ri-lr, if you're a fool.
Stories, just stories. Let us have meat, and more... more strong ale. More... very strong ale... ale.
It is very strong.
Thud..
(very drunk) Her grace Ir jessie. One sniff of the barmaids apron... heads... eh... Cor.
Thud.
I do apologise, gentlemen. I heard that. It's perfectly safe. You can come out now.
I thought it was bad luck to see the bride the night before the wedding.
Hex, knock it off.
I've got to admit, Doctor, I am well-impressed. I mean, I didn't expect Irit to hold his beer, but drinking Ori under the table? Wow.
I didn't touch a drop.
I get it. Our old friend Mickey Finn.
Where?
I nabbed a number of interesting toadstools as we passed by. The ones with white spots are noted throughout this part of the galaxy for their soporific effect upon ingestion.
So you dropped some in the beer. Smart thinking, Doctor.
I flatter myself. Now, the night is young, and we are free.
Oh, we're not gonna... you know, leg it back to the Tardis ?
+ ACE: No!
Just checking.
I want to take another look at that pillar.
What is this?
1: The Husband absconds. He is a slippery one.
2: On the night all devoted to beer and to fun.
Quiet. This Ir and this Ri. Must the best of their people be so easily gulled? I shall send them a sign. A sign of my rage.
Oh there was rum, oh there was fire, when the Ir and the Ri fell asleep by the fire.
Oh, do be quiet.
Thunder.
Great. Now we're gonna get soaked.
What is it with this pillar, Doctor?
If there were speech bubbles on that mural, it'd all be much clearer.
It's not the mural, it's the pillar itself. Ten thousand years it's been here, ten thousand years ona war-ravaged world, and what do you see?
Yeah. It's in pretty good nick.
It's untouched. There's not even graffiti.
So, there's no scallies in the future.
Oi! Hey, is it just me or is it, you know, tingling?
Get back.
Lightning.
It's all right. Rubber soles.
Rain falls.
Told you.
Doctor? How did you know the pillar was going to be struck by lightning?
I don't think it was. I think the lightning came from the pillar itself.
That sounds like it's important.
Hmm. Yes. I think it is.
You know what it is, don't you?
If I'm right, I've made a terrible mistake.
Yeah, enough with the foreboding. Is that umbrella just for show?
Of course not. (umbrella put up)
That better?
Better.
What mistake, Doctor?
Tonight I was told the story about the creation of this world, and there was something very wrong with it.
No happy ever after?
Worse. The story wasn't an attempt to tell the truth at all. It was a clear and obvious lie.
So? It was made up.
But myths aren't made up. This story was told by the Ri and the Ir, only with two different endings, as if each was tailored to a different audience.
But stories change, though.
No they don't. Look at the human story of the flood. Told in different ways by different tribes, but in the essentials and in the moral, always the same. But this story...
What about it?
The Ri tell it as a sad fable of love gone wrong. For the Ir, it's ghoulish, a tale of murder.
Nothing in common, really.
Just the one thing. The motif of the split self, the divided personality.
Huh! They like that here, don't they? Dark Husband, Shining Wife, Ri and Ir.
Yeah. It's, it's all about two sides of the same coin, isn't it?
Yes, but what coin?
You've lost me.
Divided, the Ir and the Ri were once one race, one faith.
They seem different now but once they were identical?
Like grown-up twins. You know, one has a feather-cut and one has a crop.
What did you say?
One has a feather-cut, and one has...
Of course. Twins. They should be perfectly united, but they're squabbling like children.
I blame the parents.
Exactly. The children.
The Dark Husband?
The Shining Wife?
No, no, no! There's something else. But who, what?
Er, Doctor?
Mm? Yes?
Oh, great. Angry mob with blazing torches. I feel like Frankenstein's Monster.
Doctor, Ace, and Hox. Surrender to us.
They woke up quick.
The rain must have done it. Bad luck, Doctor.
Surrender now.
Or what, Irit?
Or we'll shoot.
Ori? No guns during Festival, remember?
Laser shots fired.
Down!
Ah!
You have broken with our ancient tradition.
But the Doctor must save you, little Hox, or your friends.
Oh yeah?
I quite like shooting guns, that's all.
You must return with us to the House of Faith. The Husband and Wife must rest before the wedding.
There isn't going to be any wedding, Irit.
Nonsense. So much has happened, so much has been made ready. The wedding must take place.
No, Irit. (Shouts) I've changed my mind.
Why? Because of those myths and the lightning from the pillar?
Yes.
I'm not getting this at all.
(shouts) I withdraw my offer of marriage. I will not be the Husband.
What?
You cannot.
1 can, and I must. There will be no wedding here!
But Doctor, I thought the wedding would end the war.
Not the way I'd hoped it would. This so-called wedding...
What's wrong with it?
It's not a wedding. It's a trap.
And you've just realised that?
Yes!
Well, you've certainly picked your moment.
Doctor, I beg you. Reconsider.
I second that. Doctor, the mob are gonna tear us limb from limb if they don't get the wedding.
Little Hox speak the truth.
(shouts) He's got the last-minute jitters, that's all. Nothing to see here. Move along.
I believed when I came here this wedding would bring peace to your peoples and end this war.
And now you think that it will not?
Oh, it will end the war, and it will bring peace, of a kind. But it will also end your people. Both your peoples.
Then you leave us but one course of action.
Must we?
It'll be kinder than letting the mob have their way. Get back. Get back, you rabble. Soldier of Ri, give me your gun.
But this is Festival.
There is no more Festival. The Doctor has seen to that. Doctor, I sentence you to death.
No! I cannot allow it.
Silence, enemy, or I'll kill you too.
There really is no need for this. I
Then, do you agree to be the Dark Husband, to complete this marriage and end the endless war?
Believe me, if I thought the marriage would ensure the survival of your two peoples, I would. But it won't.
Then die.
No!
Our of the way, Shining Wife.
I'm the Wife. You can't kill me. I've done nothing wrong.
Your bravery is to be expected, but there is no Husband, and so...
No! No, you can't, because...
Hex! You can't do this.
Oh yes I can. (shouts) Ir and Ri, hear me. Hear my words. In the name of the religious unity of Tuin, and in the name of Common Faith of Ir and Ri, I offer myself as suitor.
Cheers.
Is this allowed?
The mob seem to think so.
Whatever this wedding is, Hex, it will destroy these two races.

I believe you, Doctor. But they're destroying each other anyway. But you're my friend. I can't stand by and see some slap-head from space shoot you because you don't want to go through with this stupid ceremony, so... so I'll go through with the stupid ceremony.
Figures.
Ace?
He's right, Doctor. We've no other option.
Ace!
You started this, remember.
Iâ€™m relieved. I hate to shoot friends.
I can't say that it has ever bothered me. Very well. The ceremony is back on. I shall make the necessary changes. In the meantime, bind them.
Hey!
Don't want you getting chilled heels again.
On Earth we say cold feet.
You do? Our words are better.
Never mind, Ace. En? Who'd have thought? We're getting married in the morning.
T'riffic.
Take them to the House of Faith.
Hey! What happened to Lonely Contemplation?
Some hen night this is with you two for company.
Anyoneâ€™d think you didn't want to get hitched.
I don't.
You were mad keen when it was the Doctor you were marrying.
That was different. I thought we were going to end a war, not make things worse.
Oh, come on, Ace. You'd have done the same if it was the other way round. And so would you, Doctor.
Doctor?
Attract.
Doctor?
Attract!
Yep. He's finally flipped.
You should know better than to make a flip diagnosis, Master Hex. You see, last time I was
incarcerated here I suffered an unexpected visitation.
Eh?
Come on! Attract.
Attract. Something came here by tractor beam.
Ir or Ri?
Neither. Bards of Tuin. Happen to have been repositories of ancient knowledge. Don't pretend. I know you Can see us.
Who can see us?
The person who's fomented ten thousand years of aggression between the Ir and the Ri. The person who's arranged this marriage for their own unfathomable ends.
Right. He has flipped, you know. I mean, clinically.
I warn you, whoever you are, I Know when I'm being manipulated.
Takes one to know one.
Precisely. And I will not be manipulated! So, show yourself! Show yourself!
Oh, but you have been, Doctor. And tomorrow, you'll give your companions away. (laughs)
Wake up! Wake up!
The time has come.
Just five more minutes.
No more minutes, Hex.
He could sleep in a tumble-dryer, he could.
It's your wedding day, little Hox.
Oh yeah? Ori? Ori, are you all right?
It's just... (sniffles.)... I always cry at weddings.
Bizarre. Follow me, Dark Husband, Shining Wife.
What, we're getting married like this?
Yeah, I want my bride to have the full meringue. Not looking like she's been dragged through a hedge backwards.
You will be garlanded in flowers and ribbons.
Fine for him, but what about me?
Oh, ha-ha.
We haven't time for that. You shall both be given plain robes.
Plain robes, for a wedding of Tuin.
It's okay. I didn't want it formal anyway.
What about me? I shouldn't like to miss out on the happy occasion.
Oh, but you won't. Because if either husband or wife suffers any jitters before the ceremony is over...
+ HEX: Yes?
Ori here will kill you, Doctor, before their very eyes.
I see. A shotgun wedding. Lead on.
Music playing, happy crowd.
I don't believe it. That's the Wedding March.
How come that's playing, you know, here?
You know it as the Bridal Chorus. Richard Wagner.
Yeah, but how come it's playing here.
Wagner has some unusual inspirations.
Course he did.
Those Valkyries, scourge of the Innovichi.
Shut it, you two.

[PA]: One, two... People of Ir and Ri, we are gathered here today in the shadow of Tuin's mighty pillar to celebrate an event unique in the history of those who once walked on Tuin. An event not free from complication, as you may have heard. (laughter.) An event whose consequences we cannot know, but we must trust the word of the sacred text.
What's left of them.
Doctor.
This whole wedding is like making a nuclear bomb with half the instructions missing!
[PA]: And trust in the wisdom of those who went before to guide us. Now, let us begin. You, soldier of Ri.
I come here today not alone, but with the finest of suitors. One who has offered himself freely, with no regard what the future may hold. Step forward, Hox.
+ ACE: Hex!
Oh... yes. Hex.
Behold the Dark Husband.
Cheers.
Doctor, your turn.
Oh, very well. I come here today, not alone, but with the bravest of females. A warrior and a wife. (sotto) Huh. What twaddle. (normal) And I say to you all on this new day, behold the Shining Wife.
Cheers.
This is too weird.
You're telling me.
[PA]: Husband, Wife, step forward. Good. Now. They stand...
Rumbling.
Whoa.
Got you.
What's, what is this?
[PA]: You stand on the Disc of Union. It has lain here waiting thousands of years for this moment, for the Shining Wife and the Dark Husband.
Cheers.
No, no. Ace, Hex, step off the disc.
It's just a piece of stone, Doctor.
So was Stonehenge until some idiot found the on switch.
Doctor, you must respect the ritual or else.
[PA]: And now that Wife and Husband are here, speak any who deny their union.
I'm very much against it.
[PA]: None do speak.
I said...
[PA]: And so the ceremony begins.
Oh, Lorâ€™. We're getting married. You and me, actually getting married.
It's just a ritual, Hex.
See the Disc of Union glows. Tuin approves.
I was afraid of this.
Doctor. What's happening?
Big wibble.
Being pulled in.
Oh no you don't!
Doctor, no!
Silence
Where did they go, Irit?
I er. Er, it is... a miracle.
Cheers
Wibble ends.
Ah. I hate that.
Oh, attracted again. But where to?
Judging by the length of time in sub-space and the relative gravitational shift of our surroundings...
We're underground?
Deep underground.
In the heart of Tuin itself. Show yourself!
Or at least turn the lights on!
Is this the Dark Husband?
That's me. Where are ya?
Is this the Shining Wife?
Yeah. Come on, enough theatrics. Where are you?
All around. It's coming from all around.
Well, what is it?
Isn't it obvious?
HEX+ ACE: No.
It's Tuin. The planet Tuin. It's...
Alive.

HEX: Get off me, Ori!
ORI: Man shall not move. Companion Ace, you may restore life if you wish.

HEX: Ori!
ACE: Great blond pillock...
IRIT: [PA]: One can save him.

HEX: You go, girl. Surf that crowd.
IRIT: [PA]: One shall save him.
CROWD: Save him, save him, save him...

CROWD: The Shining Wife.
ACE: Do what?
DOCTOR: (mumbling) I said... (normal) Ace, you idiot.
IRIT: Behold. Behold the Shining Wife.
ACE: Oh, that's another fine mess I've gotten myself into.
ACE: Well, how was I supposed to know it was all a trick?
DOCTOR: You played right into their hands.
HEX: Oh, come on, Doctor. Ace wasn't to know. Everyone there believed it was real. I mean, cold fire. How do they do that?
DOCTOR: Oh, it's the most basic of chemical illusions.
ACE: It was a trap, wasn't it? That's what all the Vigil of Decoy bit was about.
HEX: Oh, they didn't want one of their lot being the Shining Wife or whatever it is, so they let Ace step in.
THE DOCTOR: Absolutely. Let the newcomers do the dirty work. We're expendable.
ACE: Except the cold fire wouldn't have hurt anyone.
DOCTOR: Which means...?
HEX: Er...
ACE: The nasty part is yet to come.
DOCTOR: Precisely.
HEX: What nasty part?
DOCTOR: That is the question.
IRIT: Silence! The ritual is complete. The choice has been made.
HEX: Knock it off. No one here is in the mood.
ORI: The brave one has revealed herself. She who stands above all her kind. In her decision, she makes her choice.
ACE: Choice? I didn't make a choice. I just did what I had to do.
IRIT: Fitting words, for modesty becomes a wife.
ACE: But I don't want to be the Shining Wife.
ORI: Mark of the Shining Wife is bravery.
IRIT: The rituals are very clear.
ACE: I'm not brave, and I won't be anyone's wife.
DOCTOR: Not even to end ten thousand years of war, death and pain?
ACE: We can do that by going through one ritual?
HEX: You're crazy, both of ya. You've no idea what's coming next.
IRIT: Enough. The final night beckons.
HEX: Here we go. I've seen what happens on a normal stag night. I can't imagine what they do here.
ORI: The final night!
HEX: You'd better watch it, Doctor, if you don't want to end up chained to a lamp post in your Y-fronts.
ACE: (sighs) Oh, Hex.
HEX: In Boulogne. That's all I'm saying.
DOCTOR: And what happens on this final night?
IRIT: Both Ir and Ri must pass the night with the Dark Husband, by the Campfire of Thwarted Regret.
ORI: Keeping watch and telling stories.
HEX: Hey, I know some stories. There was this fella...
DOCTOR: Oh dear.
IRIT: No. The Husband must come with us. Alone.
DOCTOR: Oh!
HEX: Hey, put him down, Ori!
ORI: Do not try to follow us, little Hox, or...
HEX: What? The Bergils again?
ORI: Yes. And that make me... sad.
ACE: Well - what are we supposed to do till the morning?
DOCTOR: (receding) Read the Manual of Instruction.
ACE: Where?
DOCTOR: On the lectern. There's more to this than meets the eye.
IRIT: Come.
ACE: Bergils?
HEX: Don't ask. So, you marrying the Doctor? Wow.
ACE: It's just a ritual, Hex. It doesn't mean anything. I want to have a look at this manual.
HEX: Oh. It doesn't mean anything. You and him go back a long way, don't you?
ACE: And?
HEX: And you get on, you know, pretty well. Well, you're sort of... close.
ACE: Hex! We're hours from ending thousands of years of war and you want to know if... Oh. I mean, honestly.
HEX: Oh! It's all right for you. You're the Shining Wife. He's the Dark Husband, so what am I, eh? The spare part at the wedding?
ACE: Well, I'll tell you what. According to the rituals...
HEX: Yeah, yeah, the rituals.
ACE: Shut up. According to the rituals, the Shining Wife can ask someone to give her away.
HEX: What? Like her dad?
ACE: No. A friend. Someone close to her. Someone deep in her affections? Someone she can turn to.
HEX: I suppose Ori's all right. A bit hairy, but...
ACE: No, you fool, I mean you. I want you to give me away.
HEX: I know.
ACE: And?
HEX: Yeah, okay. No big deal. Are you bored now?
ACE: This Bergils business.
HEX: Yeah?
ACE: Can't be anything so bad, can it?
IRIT: Ah. A nice warm fire. I hope the flames do not distress you, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I find your sense of humour much more distressing, Irit.
IRIT: We have little time for humour in time of war, Doctor.
ORI: Ha! Ir were born without a humour gene. They can no more laugh than I can have a bald backside.
DOCTOR: It's going to be a long night.
ORI: Ale! Ale!
DOCTOR: I'll be Mother.
IRIT: The time to tell the stories of old Tuin has come.
ORI: Heed the ballads of the Bards of Tuin.
DOCTOR: Oh, are they coming?
IRIT: Not the actual Bards of Tuin, obviously.
ORI: They are long gone, dead these five score thousand years.
DOCTOR: Is that a fact. Your ale, Ori.
ORI: Foamy! Ah.
DOCTOR: And yours, Irit. It's all head, I'm afraid.
IRIT: Much like the Ir. Ah.
DOCTOR: Good health, gentlemen. So, if the ancient Bards can't make it, who's telling the tales?
ORI: I shall, for Ri.
IRIT: And I, for Ir.
DOCTOR: All right.
ORI: Full five score thousand years ago, come Bards of old.
DOCTOR: Oh dear.
IRIT: I Know. Listen to that accent. So coarse.
ORI: Can you do better, shiny-backed scum of Ir?
DOCTOR: Ori, friend, time is short, and there are no doubt many tales to tell.
ORI: Oh yes.
DOCTOR: So how about getting to the heart of the matter?
IRIT: Please.
ORI: Oh. Ah, suppose.
DOCTOR: Do your people have any stories on how this wedding came to be?
ORI: Oh yes, hundreds. Rhymes and songs and fables.
DOCTOR: Something short, that doesn't rhyme.
ORI: Oh well, there is one, but it's a tale for children.
DOCTOR: I'm all ears. Drink up, Irit.
ORI: Hear then, my story. Ah. The Story of the Planet and the Wanderer.
DOCTOR: Go on.
ORI: The story goes like this. Once upon a time...
IRIT: Ha.
ORI: ... there was a Wanderer. Man was he not, nor woman, but only... Wanderer. And the Wanderer came to a barren world and entered it, and the world was no longer barren.
IRIT: I hate it already.
DOCTOR: I'm enjoying it. Who was this Wanderer?
ORI: And the Wanderer named the world, and the name was Tuin. And the world named the Wanderer, and the name was Ri-Ir.
IRIT: Rubbish. The name was Ir-Ri.
DOCTOR: Does it matter?
ORI: + IRIT: Yes!
ORI: The Wanderer became estranged from the planet. The Wanderer longed to wander again, yet also the Wanderer longed to be with Tuin. And the soul of the Wanderer was divided and stretched and cut, until it became...
IRIT: Two souls. We have this story too. A superior telling.
DOCTOR: Naturally. Drink up.
ORI: And those souls being divided, were not able to wander, nor stay with the planet. They became...
DOCTOR: Ir and Ri. The moons. Trapped in near-space, unable to leave Tuin's orbit, or to return.
IRIT: A story for children, and you got it wrong.
ORI: I did not.
DOCTOR: So how did your people tell it?
IRIT: In our version, Ir and Ri are the children of the Wanderer, not the Wanderer's spirit. And they are not
IRIT: poor orphans floating in the sky. They are outcasts because they killed their parents.
DOCTOR: Extraordinary.
IRIT: Yes. And so they were hanged, hanged in the sky. Guilty of killing Mother Tuin, and Father Ir-Ri. Or itâ€™s Ri-lr, if you're a fool.
ORI: Stories, just stories. Let us have meat, and more... more strong ale. More... very strong ale... ale.
IRIT: It is very strong.
ORI: (very drunk) Her grace Ir jessie. One sniff of the barmaids apron... heads... eh... Cor.
DOCTOR: I do apologise, gentlemen. I heard that. It's perfectly safe. You can come out now.
HEX: I thought it was bad luck to see the bride the night before the wedding.
ACE: Hex, knock it off.
HEX: I've got to admit, Doctor, I am well-impressed. I mean, I didn't expect Irit to hold his beer, but drinking Ori under the table? Wow.
DOCTOR: I didn't touch a drop.
ACE: I get it. Our old friend Mickey Finn.
HEX: Where?
DOCTOR: I nabbed a number of interesting toadstools as we passed by. The ones with white spots are noted throughout this part of the galaxy for their soporific effect upon ingestion.
ACE: So you dropped some in the beer. Smart thinking, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I flatter myself. Now, the night is young, and we are free.
HEX: Oh, we're not gonna... you know, leg it back to the Tardis ?
DOCTOR: + ACE: No!
HEX: Just checking.
DOCTOR: I want to take another look at that pillar.
TUIN: What is this?
BARD: 1: The Husband absconds. He is a slippery one.
BARD: 2: On the night all devoted to beer and to fun.
TUIN: Quiet. This Ir and this Ri. Must the best of their people be so easily gulled? I shall send them a sign. A sign of my rage.
BARDS: Oh there was rum, oh there was fire, when the Ir and the Ri fell asleep by the fire.
TUIN: Oh, do be quiet.
HEX: Great. Now we're gonna get soaked.
ACE: What is it with this pillar, Doctor?
HEX: If there were speech bubbles on that mural, it'd all be much clearer.
DOCTOR: It's not the mural, it's the pillar itself. Ten thousand years it's been here, ten thousand years ona war-ravaged world, and what do you see?
ACE: Yeah. It's in pretty good nick.
DOCTOR: It's untouched. There's not even graffiti.
ACE: So, there's no scallies in the future.
HEX: Oi! Hey, is it just me or is it, you know, tingling?
DOCTOR: Get back.
HEX: It's all right. Rubber soles.
HEX: Told you.
ACE: Doctor? How did you know the pillar was going to be struck by lightning?
DOCTOR: I don't think it was. I think the lightning came from the pillar itself.
ACE: That sounds like it's important.
DOCTOR: Hmm. Yes. I think it is.
ACE: You know what it is, don't you?
DOCTOR: If I'm right, I've made a terrible mistake.
HEX: Yeah, enough with the foreboding. Is that umbrella just for show?
DOCTOR: Of course not. (umbrella put up)
DOCTOR: That better?
HEX: Better.
ACE: What mistake, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Tonight I was told the story about the creation of this world, and there was something very wrong with it.
HEX: No happy ever after?
DOCTOR: Worse. The story wasn't an attempt to tell the truth at all. It was a clear and obvious lie.
ACE: So? It was made up.
DOCTOR: But myths aren't made up. This story was told by the Ri and the Ir, only with two different endings, as if each was tailored to a different audience.
HEX: But stories change, though.
DOCTOR: No they don't. Look at the human story of the flood. Told in different ways by different tribes, but in the essentials and in the moral, always the same. But this story...
ACE: What about it?
DOCTOR: The Ri tell it as a sad fable of love gone wrong. For the Ir, it's ghoulish, a tale of murder.
ACE: Nothing in common, really.
DOCTOR: Just the one thing. The motif of the split self, the divided personality.
ACE: Huh! They like that here, don't they? Dark Husband, Shining Wife, Ri and Ir.
HEX: Yeah. It's, it's all about two sides of the same coin, isn't it?
DOCTOR: Yes, but what coin?
HEX: You've lost me.
DOCTOR: Divided, the Ir and the Ri were once one race, one faith.
ACE: They seem different now but once they were identical?
HEX: Like grown-up twins. You know, one has a feather-cut and one has a crop.
DOCTOR: What did you say?
HEX: One has a feather-cut, and one has...
DOCTOR: Of course. Twins. They should be perfectly united, but they're squabbling like children.
ACE: I blame the parents.
DOCTOR: Exactly. The children.
HEX: The Dark Husband?
ACE: The Shining Wife?
DOCTOR: No, no, no! There's something else. But who, what?
ACE: Er, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Mm? Yes?
HEX: Oh, great. Angry mob with blazing torches. I feel like Frankenstein's Monster.
ORI: Doctor, Ace, and Hox. Surrender to us.
HEX: They woke up quick.
ACE: The rain must have done it. Bad luck, Doctor.
IRIT: Surrender now.
ACE: Or what, Irit?
ORI: Or we'll shoot.
HEX: Ori? No guns during Festival, remember?
ACE: Down!
DOCTOR: Ah!
IRIT: You have broken with our ancient tradition.
ORI: But the Doctor must save you, little Hox, or your friends.
ACE: Oh yeah?
ORI: I quite like shooting guns, that's all.
IRIT: You must return with us to the House of Faith. The Husband and Wife must rest before the wedding.
DOCTOR: There isn't going to be any wedding, Irit.
IRIT: Nonsense. So much has happened, so much has been made ready. The wedding must take place.
DOCTOR: No, Irit. (Shouts) I've changed my mind.
ACE: Why? Because of those myths and the lightning from the pillar?
DOCTOR: Yes.
HEX: I'm not getting this at all.
DOCTOR: (shouts) I withdraw my offer of marriage. I will not be the Husband.
IRIT: What?
ORI: You cannot.
DOCTOR: 1 can, and I must. There will be no wedding here!
ACE: But Doctor, I thought the wedding would end the war.
DOCTOR: Not the way I'd hoped it would. This so-called wedding...
HEX: What's wrong with it?
DOCTOR: It's not a wedding. It's a trap.
HEX: And you've just realised that?
DOCTOR: Yes!
ACE: Well, you've certainly picked your moment.
IRIT: Doctor, I beg you. Reconsider.
HEX: I second that. Doctor, the mob are gonna tear us limb from limb if they don't get the wedding.
ORI: Little Hox speak the truth.
HEX: (shouts) He's got the last-minute jitters, that's all. Nothing to see here. Move along.
DOCTOR: I believed when I came here this wedding would bring peace to your peoples and end this war.
IRIT: And now you think that it will not?
DOCTOR: Oh, it will end the war, and it will bring peace, of a kind. But it will also end your people. Both your peoples.
IRIT: Then you leave us but one course of action.
ORI: Must we?
IRIT: It'll be kinder than letting the mob have their way. Get back. Get back, you rabble. Soldier of Ri, give me your gun.
ORI: But this is Festival.
IRIT: There is no more Festival. The Doctor has seen to that. Doctor, I sentence you to death.
ORI: No! I cannot allow it.
IRIT: Silence, enemy, or I'll kill you too.
DOCTOR: There really is no need for this. I
IRIT: Then, do you agree to be the Dark Husband, to complete this marriage and end the endless war?
DOCTOR: Believe me, if I thought the marriage would ensure the survival of your two peoples, I would. But it won't.
IRIT: Then die.
ACE: No!
IRIT: Our of the way, Shining Wife.
ACE: I'm the Wife. You can't kill me. I've done nothing wrong.
IRIT: Your bravery is to be expected, but there is no Husband, and so...
HEX: No! No, you can't, because...
DOCTOR: Hex! You can't do this.
HEX: Oh yes I can. (shouts) Ir and Ri, hear me. Hear my words. In the name of the religious unity of Tuin, and in the name of Common Faith of Ir and Ri, I offer myself as suitor.
ORI: Is this allowed?
IRIT: The mob seem to think so.
DOCTOR: Whatever this wedding is, Hex, it will destroy these two races.
HEX: I believe you, Doctor. But they're destroying each other anyway. But you're my friend. I can't stand by and see some slap-head from space shoot you because you don't want to go through with this stupid ceremony, so... so I'll go through with the stupid ceremony.
ACE: Figures.
DOCTOR: Ace?
ACE: He's right, Doctor. We've no other option.
DOCTOR: Ace!
ACE: You started this, remember.
ORI: Iâ€™m relieved. I hate to shoot friends.
IRIT: I can't say that it has ever bothered me. Very well. The ceremony is back on. I shall make the necessary changes. In the meantime, bind them.
ACE: Hey!
ORI: Don't want you getting chilled heels again.
ACE: On Earth we say cold feet.
ORI: You do? Our words are better.
HEX: Never mind, Ace. En? Who'd have thought? We're getting married in the morning.
ACE: T'riffic.
IRIT: Take them to the House of Faith.
HEX: Hey! What happened to Lonely Contemplation?
ACE: Some hen night this is with you two for company.
HEX: Anyoneâ€™d think you didn't want to get hitched.
ACE: I don't.
HEX: You were mad keen when it was the Doctor you were marrying.
ACE: That was different. I thought we were going to end a war, not make things worse.
HEX: Oh, come on, Ace. You'd have done the same if it was the other way round. And so would you, Doctor.
ACE: Doctor?
DOCTOR: Attract.
HEX: Doctor?
DOCTOR: Attract!
HEX: Yep. He's finally flipped.
DOCTOR: You should know better than to make a flip diagnosis, Master Hex. You see, last time I was
DOCTOR: incarcerated here I suffered an unexpected visitation.
HEX: Eh?
DOCTOR: Come on! Attract.
ACE: Attract. Something came here by tractor beam.
HEX: Ir or Ri?
DOCTOR: Neither. Bards of Tuin. Happen to have been repositories of ancient knowledge. Don't pretend. I know you Can see us.
ACE: Who can see us?
DOCTOR: The person who's fomented ten thousand years of aggression between the Ir and the Ri. The person who's arranged this marriage for their own unfathomable ends.
HEX: Right. He has flipped, you know. I mean, clinically.
DOCTOR: I warn you, whoever you are, I Know when I'm being manipulated.
ACE: Takes one to know one.
DOCTOR: Precisely. And I will not be manipulated! So, show yourself! Show yourself!
TUIN: Oh, but you have been, Doctor. And tomorrow, you'll give your companions away. (laughs)
ORI: Wake up! Wake up!
IRIT: The time has come.
HEX: Just five more minutes.
DOCTOR: No more minutes, Hex.
ACE: He could sleep in a tumble-dryer, he could.
ORI: It's your wedding day, little Hox.
HEX: Oh yeah? Ori? Ori, are you all right?
ORI: It's just... (sniffles.)... I always cry at weddings.
IRIT: Bizarre. Follow me, Dark Husband, Shining Wife.
ACE: What, we're getting married like this?
HEX: Yeah, I want my bride to have the full meringue. Not looking like she's been dragged through a hedge backwards.
ORI: You will be garlanded in flowers and ribbons.
ACE: Fine for him, but what about me?
HEX: Oh, ha-ha.
IRIT: We haven't time for that. You shall both be given plain robes.
ORI: Plain robes, for a wedding of Tuin.
HEX: It's okay. I didn't want it formal anyway.
DOCTOR: What about me? I shouldn't like to miss out on the happy occasion.
IRIT: Oh, but you won't. Because if either husband or wife suffers any jitters before the ceremony is over...
ACE: + HEX: Yes?
IRIT: Ori here will kill you, Doctor, before their very eyes.
DOCTOR: I see. A shotgun wedding. Lead on.
ACE: I don't believe it. That's the Wedding March.
HEX: How come that's playing, you know, here?
DOCTOR: You know it as the Bridal Chorus. Richard Wagner.
ACE: Yeah, but how come it's playing here.
DOCTOR: Wagner has some unusual inspirations.
HEX: Course he did.
DOCTOR: Those Valkyries, scourge of the Innovichi.
ACE: Shut it, you two.
IRIT: [PA]: One, two... People of Ir and Ri, we are gathered here today in the shadow of Tuin's mighty pillar to celebrate an event unique in the history of those who once walked on Tuin. An event not free from complication, as you may have heard. (laughter.) An event whose consequences we cannot know, but we must trust the word of the sacred text.
DOCTOR: What's left of them.
ACE: Doctor.
DOCTOR: This whole wedding is like making a nuclear bomb with half the instructions missing!
IRIT: [PA]: And trust in the wisdom of those who went before to guide us. Now, let us begin. You, soldier of Ri.
ORI: I come here today not alone, but with the finest of suitors. One who has offered himself freely, with no regard what the future may hold. Step forward, Hox.
DOCTOR: + ACE: Hex!
ORI: Oh... yes. Hex.
ORI: Behold the Dark Husband.
ORI: Doctor, your turn.
DOCTOR: Oh, very well. I come here today, not alone, but with the bravest of females. A warrior and a wife. (sotto) Huh. What twaddle. (normal) And I say to you all on this new day, behold the Shining Wife.
ACE: This is too weird.
HEX: You're telling me.
IRIT: [PA]: Husband, Wife, step forward. Good. Now. They stand...
HEX: Whoa.
ACE: Got you.
HEX: What's, what is this?
IRIT: [PA]: You stand on the Disc of Union. It has lain here waiting thousands of years for this moment, for the Shining Wife and the Dark Husband.
DOCTOR: No, no. Ace, Hex, step off the disc.
HEX: It's just a piece of stone, Doctor.
DOCTOR: So was Stonehenge until some idiot found the on switch.
ORI: Doctor, you must respect the ritual or else.
IRIT: [PA]: And now that Wife and Husband are here, speak any who deny their union.
DOCTOR: I'm very much against it.
IRIT: [PA]: None do speak.
DOCTOR: I said...
IRIT: [PA]: And so the ceremony begins.
HEX: Oh, Lorâ€™. We're getting married. You and me, actually getting married.
ACE: It's just a ritual, Hex.
IRIT: See the Disc of Union glows. Tuin approves.
DOCTOR: I was afraid of this.
ACE: Doctor. What's happening?
HEX: Being pulled in.
DOCTOR: Oh no you don't!
ORI: Doctor, no!
ORI: Where did they go, Irit?
IRIT: I er. Er, it is... a miracle.
HEX: Ah. I hate that.
ACE: Oh, attracted again. But where to?
DOCTOR: Judging by the length of time in sub-space and the relative gravitational shift of our surroundings...
HEX: We're underground?
ACE: Deep underground.
DOCTOR: In the heart of Tuin itself. Show yourself!
HEX: Or at least turn the lights on!
TUIN: Is this the Dark Husband?
HEX: That's me. Where are ya?
TUIN: Is this the Shining Wife?
ACE: Yeah. Come on, enough theatrics. Where are you?
DOCTOR: All around. It's coming from all around.
HEX: Well, what is it?
DOCTOR: Isn't it obvious?
DOCTOR: HEX+ ACE: No.
DOCTOR: It's Tuin. The planet Tuin. It's...
TUIN: Alive.

elements.text: [Part Four]
I thought so. Show yourself.
I shall.
Rumble.
Behind you.
Better?
A rock-face. Very amusing.
That face. Doctor, look. It's Irit. He's Irit.
And from your angle, Master Hex?
I don't see Irit, just... Hey, but it's Ori. See?
Not really.
Round here. Look, if you squint.
It looks like both of them.
Of course I do. I am Tuin. I am their parent.
Mother and father of Ri and Ir.
But they're people, and this is a planet.
Tuin is the soul of the planet, Hex, the spirit.
And she or he gave birth to the Ir and the Ri.
But it's a rock.
I can show myself in earth and fire, air and water.
Elementary.
My dear Watson.
He never said that, Sherlock Holmes. It's a common misconception.
Oh, whatever.

As I was saying, it's elementary. A creature of the elements, whose life-forces have polluted all of Tuin. Its blue grasses, its green seas, the creatures that form from the scum of those seas that flapped out onto the broiling mud billions of years ago.
And evolved into the Ri and the Ir.
The original Tuinese, both Ri and Ir combined.
You are perceptive, Doctor.
And what are you, Tuin? What were you once? Above, the Ri and the Ir, they call you a god.
And so lam.
Ah, but that's the God Paradox, isn't it? A creator god must himself be created, so who created you?
You got him there, Doctor.
Rumble.
You blaspheme.
Too easy, Tuin. Too, too easy. I'll tell you what you are.
Bow down. Bow down before me.
You're a factory. A life factory. The core of an artificial world around which mass has formed.
You have no proof.
Oh yes I have. The pillar.
The pillar?

Through which you channel earth and fire, air and water. Through which you manufacture thunder and lightning, through which you created life. It's engineered to it, the pillar. Perfectly engineered. A precision mechanism. It didn't evolve, it didn't grow. Face it, Tuin.
You're a fake.
The earth convulses.
The marriage ceremony has begun.
Praise be to Tuin. The wedding will bring peace to all and an end to war. Ours will be a golden age.
Yes. Yes, but have you considered, Ori dullard...
Yes.
If, when the prophecy comes true, and this war, this ancient war ends.
Yes.
What are we going to do?
Er.
Are you done, Tuin?
Yeah. Enough already with the temper tantrums .
Don't antagonise him, Hex. Much more of that sort of thing and he'll split this planet asunder.
Ah, and I have considered it. But my children, their faith remains strong.
Faith and a bogus creed that demands they destroy one another?
What happened to don't antagonise him?
I feel their pain, Doctor, their terrible suffering.
Yeah. I'm convinced.
I imagine it's more of a deep-down spiritual pain, the kind that doesn't necessarily show.
The scars of war are writ upon my surface.
You started it. Don't expect us to feel sorry for you.
You started the war?
Well, of course he did.
Why?
For years my children, the Tuinese, they worshipped me without question.
They still do.
It wasn't enough.
Why do gods always have such massive egos?
Because we are gods.
Stupid question, really.
My children prayed to me, built temples to me, gave thanks to me.
Then what? They forgot your birthday?
They grew up, Hex. They saw that, marvellous though you are, Tuin, even for a fairly small sentient planet, they saw that they too were marvellous creations. And, as every child does...
They wanted to be independent.
They wanted to leave home.
But Tuin didn't like that, did you? Oh, no, you liked the dancing around and the praising and the celebrating all right, but the independence, the self-reliance? No.
They were disobedient.
And so you punished them.
With earthquakes, and hurricanes, fire and brimstone, and more. Great days.
But they escaped you even then, didn't they? They fled to the moons of Ir and Ri.
They were ungrateful.
And so you cursed them with war, set the Ir and the Ri against one other.
Yeah, but how?
The pillar. Two gene clouds, each targeted at each of the moons. The Ir gained their characteristics.
Baldness and cunning?
And the Ri gained theirs.
Boldness and... gingerness.
Such trivial differences. The perfect recipe for ten thousand years of war.
Silence. The wedding will proceed.
Oh. I'd forgotten all about that.
You had?
I think we can all forget about the wedding.
She is the Shining Wife. He is the Dark Husband. The wedding must commence to bring peace eternal to Tuin.

Yes. You see, that's where I went wrong. I knew that the wedding would indeed bring peace to Tuin, but what I hadn't quite realised was, what that meant. Not peace to Tuin as in the end of a horrible war, but a different kind of peace to a different Tuin.
Proceed. Proceed with the wedding, or...
Oh, son et lumiÃ©re. Please, you don't impress me, Tuin, with all this noise.
You need this wedding. Really need it. Why?
The wedding represents the very future of Tuin. Without it, I cannot survive.
Tuin is displeased.
A thunderbolt.
He sends lightning.
The skies are boiling, red with Tuin's rage.
Leave! Flee, from Tuin's anger! Flee!
Hah. Where's your courage now, soldier of Ri?
And where's your wisdom? The wedding has gone wrong. Tuin will destroy us all.
If that's the case...
It is.
Then what was all our fighting for? If the world ends now, and if Ir and Ri spin off their axes, what was it for?
Let's go to Tuin, call the wedding off, so we may continue the war.
Yes, yes. Ori of Ri, you speak with wisdom.
I do?
You do. And I, Irit of Ir, I can show courage.
You can? I, I mean, you can.
We shall go to Tuin together.
How?
There is only one way. By the Disc of Union.
But that means...
Yes. Yes. Come with me, Ori of Ri. I shall be the Husband.
And I shall be the Wife.
I will become perfect. I will end my own impurity.
Eh?
I think I'm beginning to understand.
Well, we're not.
Silence. The wedding will begin now, or I shall shatter the whole of Tuin.
Doctor, he means it.
He's nuts.
Is that a clinical diagnosis, Master Hex?
Yes!
I think you're right. Tuin, that's enough!
Stand forward, Husband.
All right.
Stand forward, Wife.
What now?
Do you, Dark Husband, meet the challenge of this Wife?
Challenge? Yeah! Yeah, yeah. Course I do.
Do you, Shining Wife, meet the challenge of this Husband?
It's just a ritual, you said.
It's more than that. But I still don't see...
Silence. Do you, Shining Wife, meet the challenge of this Husband?
(sotto) I do.
Speak up.
I do, all right? I do. Happy now?
That's it kid, you and me, happy ever after.
Bog off, Hex.
Bards, bring forth the rings.
What?
Oh no.
Tractor beam.
We are Tuin's ancient Bards. We recite and rhyme and sing. Hail Husband, hail Wife, here's to your conjoining .
Oh, for a minute I thought they were going to murder us.
No, they're quite happy murdering poetry.
The Rings of Futurity.
That's way too big for a ring.
I think you wear it on your head.
Crown them.
1: Cunning Husband, son of Ir. Here be your crown may you know no fear.
2: Courageous Wife, daughter of Ri. Here be your crown, may you never flee.
Grinding of stone as crown is put on.
Is that it? Are we done?
Energy makes Ace and Hex cry out.
Ace, Hex! If you harm them, I'll...
I will never harm my children. Hex of Ir, Ace of Ri.
+ HEX: Yes, mighty Tuin.
You are Husband, you are Wife.
+ HEX: Yes.
You, Husband, may now kill the Wife, and you, Wife, the Husband.
+ HEX: We will.
Noooooooooo0!
I come here today not alone, but with the finest of suitors. One who has offered himself freely, with no regard what the future may hold. Step forward, Irit.
I have stepped forward, Ri fool.
Oh, yes. Behold the Dark Husband.
I come here today not alone, but the bravest of females, blah-blah. Step forward, Ori. Step forward.
On it!
Behold the Shining Wife. Er...
We stand on the Disc of Union.
Mmm? Oh, I know! We stand on the Disc of Union that has lain here waiting thousands of years for this moment. This Shining Wife and the Dark Husband.
Speak, any who deny their union.
They've all gone.
And see, the Disc of Union glows.
And so...
The ceremony...
Wibble.
Wibble.
What place is this?
Where - where are we?
Just in time.
What is the meaning of this intrusion?
(monotone) The Husband aches to kill his wife.
(monotone) The Wife longs to slay her husband.
Soon. What are these creatures doing here?
Oh, just a couple of witnesses. Family members, if you like.
No.
Why, it cannot be.
The old engravings.
The stories.
Yes. It is Tuin, the mother and father of Ir and Ri, the sentience to whom you bow down each and every day. Smaller in real life, isn't he?
I - I- I cannot speak.
Ir, you dust-head.
Ri cretin.
You are my children? You?
We are. I am Ori of the Ri.
I am Irit of the Ir.
You are the children who despise me, as I despise you. You are the spawn who lack respect.
But... but we fought a war in your name.
We have battled aeons to win your respect.
I say again, you are nothing to me.
I don't understand.
But I do. Your peoples - the Ri and the Ir - both created by Tuin, are two halves of one being.
This cannot be. We're different. We're old enemies.
Yes, I know all that. The warring halves, different parts of the same thing, Ying and Yang, Romulus and Remus.
1: Mighty heroes of legend and lore.
2: Duelliptically split in days of long yore.
The same, but different.
But Doctor, if we're the same, then why have we fought for so long?
Why indeed?
They are flawed. They are faulty. I was Tuin, perfect and whole. I sundered my self to create you, and all I created were two broken vessels.
Ah, now we're getting to the bottom of it.
But, but... we haven't done... we've done nothing to offend you.
We have obeyed all your precepts to the letter.
You are specks on my purity. My Bards?
1: Yes, mighty Tuin.
2: You called, mighty Tuin?
Kill them both. Oh, and this Doctor.
Verily!
Ha! Stone warriors, you don't scare Ori of the Ri.
Nor Irit of the Ir.
Watch out!
Ori and Irit cry out.
Husband. Wife.
Leave them alone.
Detract.
No!
Detractor beam.
Tuin?
Ace is gone.
1: So Husband And Wife may fully conjoin.
2: In battle.
These, these are stone creatures.
No, we cannot defeat them.
You don't have to. On their foreheads, press One" Just do it.
1: Narrative history selected.
2: For ninety hundred year, ere Tuin spread its wings.
What's this?
History.
2: Tuin's priests determined this...
We don't have to listen. Help me get their heads off.
Heads?
Tuin?
1: Should they fall from Tuin's ways.
Oh, it's light to pull.
2: To protect her people near and far.
Good. Now...
You make knots of its innards.
Will you shut the other one up before it starts to do the knight-listing thing.
2: And each then gave...
Thank you.
How does this help? We should seek out Tuin.
He's gone to ground. If I can just tune this Bard to the frequency of that last detractor beam...
+ IRIT: Yes?
We should be able to jump from this reception to wherever Tuin's got the honeymoon suite.
The wedding continues?
Well, of course the wedding continues.
But what sort of wedding is it where a husband kills his wife?
Don't you see? Tuin divided itself when it made you. Now it hates itself.
Tuin cannot hate itself. Tuin is divine.
Oh, Tuin is deeply, deeply unhappy. He rejected his own children. He set them against one another in the hope that a good long war might help them rediscover their devotion to him. Only...
Only what, Doctor?
He divided you. Both Ir and Ri think they're Tuin's chosen people.
And we will be.
When the final victory comes.
But you're all his children. He loves both Ir and Ri alike, so how does he choose between you?
He... cannot.
Hence this wedding. A process by which the bravest of the Ri and the most cunning of the Ir join together to challenge one another. The victor will be chosen. The most worthy, the most devout.
And the loser?
That's what I'm worried about. Oh!
Doctor?
What is it?
There's something written on the inside of the Bard's brain-pan.
Just squiggles.
Ah, but I can read the language.
And what do these squiggles tell you, Doctor?
Everything.
Now begins the Wedding of Tuin. Now ends the division of us. Now comes the new time. Dark Husband, Shining Wife, are you prepared?
+ HEX: We are.
And have you chosen your weapons?
+ HEX: We have.
Fine blades, forged by the ancient Tuinese, before they turned their backs on me.
+ HEX: What must we do, mighty Tuin?
Here beneath my pillar, here is the altar of transfiguration. The one who stands there will be chosen. You must prevent the other from reaching the altar.
+ HEX: We will.
Dearly beloved, the moment has come.
Wibble.
That's right. Hold on.
What?
That was quick. Ori, Irit?
+ IRIT: Doctor?
Ace and Hex. Grab them and don't hurt them.
Back. I am the Dark Husband.
I am the Shining Wife.
+ HEX: You will not prevent our transfiguration.
Transfiguration? Oh no, that's...
The altar of transfiguration, Doctor. The ultimate destiny of Ir or Ri, of Dark Husband or Shining Wife.
That's a genetic condenser.
Are... are these ritual words?

Each of them is part of me. Half of me. I am Tuin. My affections are divided. The Dark Husband is Ir - cunning, wise, devious. The Shining Wife is Ri - brave, impulsive, violent. Both are Tuin, yet one is flawed. And so they will fight.
Tuin confuses oneness and unity with right. He can't choose between the two halves of his being.
And he will make his choice through combat? This is too cruel.
I thought you Ri loved to fight.
But there is no honour in this. There is no fairness. He uses them like a tyrant who sets his two pet dogs to fighting.
Well, that's your war in one sentence.
This is madness.

Oh! It's even madder than you think. The victor will be genetically condensed here on this altar, pumped up through the pillar, to be showered all over the surface of the planet above. A gene cloud that will transform all life.
If Ir wins, all will become Ir. If Ri wins, all will become Ri.
But... but Ace, and Hox.
They're human.
They... they are your champions, the best that Ir and Ri can offer.
They're human. Whoever wins, both the Ir and the Ri will be destroyed, transfigured, turned human as your pillar pumps out its confetti of death.
You would do this, Tuin?
You would destroy both Ri and Ir alike?
I... 1... Edo... I, I cannot...
Doubts creeping in, Tuin? A shred of realisation?
Tuin, you are evil!
You are wrong.
There. There, do you see? Both Ir and Ri reject me.
No. No, no!
Yes, yes, yes. I shall destroy them. I shall destroy both Ir and Ri. The wedding continues. By the power of Tuin, creator of Ri and the Ir, I bring together the Shining Wife and the Dark Husband.
No, we stand against you, Dark Husband, Shining Wife.
United.
Ir to Ri.
And Ri for Ir.
You shall not ascend the alter.
But we shall.
Together.
Don't just talk about it. Husband, Wife, kill them. Kill my faithless children.
+ HEX: Yah!
No!
+ HEX: Do you stand before us too?
Ace, Hex, whatever thoughts are in your head, you must resist them.
I am the Shining Wife. I am Ri. I am impulse. I am brave. I do not wait for orders.
I am the Dark Husband. I am Ir. I am the thinker, the planner, he who waits then strikes.
But this makes no sense. He's not Ir.
She is not Ri.
Don't you see? Nobody is. The Ir and the Ri are the same people. Two sides of one coin. There is no Ir, and there are no Ri.
Enough.
Listen to me. You are Hex and Ace. You're currently in the thrall of a creature that hates itself, a creature that longs to cut its soul in half.
Kill him. Kill him, Husband. Kill him, Wife.
Hex, Ace, think. Remember who you are, and what you are.
I am heat. I am impulse. I am hate.
Ace, you are all these things, and you are the opposite of those things. Hex?
I am cold. I am cunning. I am hate.
Hex, you're the most impulsive of us all. Remember who you are. Fix on those memories. Remember your feelings. Remember something you love, someone you love.
Something. Someone.
Yes, yes. Look at Ace.
My Shining Wife. (clatter) Ace.
No. No. Ignore him. Kill him.
Ace, you look at Hex.
My Dark Husband. (clatter) Hex.
Now, very gently, raise your right hands, both of you, and take the ring from the other's head.
Ace?
Hex?
Does this mean, we're not married any more?
No, no. I shall destroy all Tuin. Begin the Transfiguration.
Doctor, the altar!
But there's nothing there.
Oh yes, there is.
Tuin.
With the last reserves of my physical existence, I shall transform all life on Tuin. Transform it, dead.
Doctor, he can't.
Can he?
He gave life to all of Tuin. If he condenses himself, it'll be like turning off every gene in the Ir and the Ri.
So be it. If they do not worship Tuin, then Tuin will die. Let them die with Tuin.
Doctor, do something.
The Bards, Doctor. What was in the Bards' heads?
Not now. Ori.
The Bards' head?
Ir see squiggles.
What? What? What?
What do they mean, Doctor?
No!
In the language of the fabled World-shapers of the Large Magellanic Cloud, it means simply reject.
Reject?
Tuin, the Bards, the pillar, all part of a faulty planet-building kit. A kit that failed quality control. A kit that was defective.
No!
Thrown spinning into space. A factory second. Unwanted. A reject.
I transform you all. Transform all life. Transform it, dead.
Doctor?
Do something, Doctor.
There's nothing I can do.
But...? Was that a but?
It was. It was a but.
Doctor!
He means, soldier Ri, that there's nothing he can do to save the Ir or the Ri.
Because he is neither Ir nor Ri. Yes.
Join with me, Ri Wife. Join with me on the altar.
I will, Ir Husband.
Ori? Ori! No!
Goodbye, Doctor. Goodbye, Ace.
Goodbye, Hex.
Explosion.
Was that it?
They're dead, aren't they?
Not exactly, Hex.
What do you mean, not exactly?
Fireworks. Talking and party in the background.
Hey, the Festival's started up again.
Can't you tell? The war's over, Ace.
It can't just end like that, in a flash.
It can. Look. That fella there, the Ri. He's...
Moulting is the word I think you're looking for.
Lots of Irs going ginger on top.
There's something in the air, and the water, and the wind and the earth. A transforming charge of Ori, Irit, and yes, Tuin itself.
They're one people again.
It'll take time, but soon, they'll barely notice the differences. Who knows? They might even start to marry one another.
Then that's it? War ended, harmony restored, job done?
Exactly. Now, let's be off before they start giving us medals. I hate medals.
Well, you don't get off without this.
A kiss.
What was that for?
When you told me down there to think of all the things I love, I thought of you, Doctor. And the Tardis. And this life. So that's what the kiss was for.
I... thank you, Ace.
(retching) Please. Beer tent, anyone?
(distant) Ace, Hex, come on.
Hey, you didn't say.
Say what?
What it was you thought about, you know, underneath the pillar.
Oh. You know.
No I don't.
Stuff.
Stuff?
All right then. Football.
Football?
Yeah, football.
(sighs) Thomas Hector Schofield, you have no soul. Coming, Doctor.
Football. And... other things.
